column22:
A, an, one:
In Romansh, the word for "a"/"an" and "one" is the same. It agrees with the gender of the noun.

And:
The form "ed" is used before vowels, otherwise "e".

Or, nor:
In the northern idioms "ni" may be either "or" or "nor" and "nini" may be either "eitheror" or "neithernor".

Yes:
All versions of Romansh have a word like "gea" for "yes" (as opposed to "no").
Puter and Vallader have another short word, "hai", that is used to signal agreement with the speaker in a conversation. Actually, a Romansh conversation in the Engadin is almost impossible without "hai"!
column23:
Gea:
En l'englais pledà aud'ins savens "yeh" enstagl da "yes".

column22:
Expressions of time:
At three o'clock = A las trais.
column23:
A (cun l'ura):
"A las trais" = "At three (o'clock).
column24:
(1) Jau arriv en scola a las otg." = "I get to school at eight (o'clock)."
(2) "Nus finin la scola a las quatter." = "We finish school at four (o'clock)."

column22:
Romansh: a, ad:
The form "ad" is used before vowels.
In the Engadin (Puter and Vallader ) a "polite a" (with no additional meaning) is often added before the names of people as the direct objects of sentences.

On (3):
On or in + the name of a road is "a" in Romansh

Romansh: da, dad:
The form "dad" is used before vowels.

About:
"Da" ("dad" or "d'" before vowels) is used for about in the sense of talking, writing, etc. about something.
column24:
Tschantscha da tia famiglia. =
Talk about your family.

column22:
Definite article:
The definite article ("the") has many different forms in Romansh. It varies with number and gender and may also change if followed by a vowel. It also combines with some common prepositions to form a single word.

Definite article:
The definite article ("the") has many different forms in Romansh. It varies with number and gender and may also change if followed by a vowel. It also combines with some common prepositions to form a single word.

Definite article:
The definite article ("the") has many different forms in Romansh. It varies with number and gender and may also change if followed by a vowel. It also combines with some common prepositions to form a single word.

Definite article:
The definite article ("the") has many different forms in Romansh. It varies with number and gender and may also change if followed by a vowel. It also combines with some common prepositions to form a single word.

A, an, one:
In Romansh, the word for "a"/"an" and "one" is the same. It agrees with the gender of the noun.

One:
"Ins" is used in the standardised language and the northern idioms more frequently than "one" in impersonal sentences in English. It also corresponds to the English impersonal "they" (or the French "on" or German "man").
Example: "ins di..." could be translated as "one says", "people say", "it is said", etc.
In the southern idioms, a totally different structure is usually used, i.e. a reflexive verb (similar to Italian).
column23:
Ins:
Il pronom impersunal englais "one" correspunda be approximativamain al rumantsch "ins" e vegn duvrà pli pauc. Il "they" impersunal u in 'autra expressiun è savens meglier en englais.

column22:
Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "me" or "to me":
(1) "ma", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(a) mai", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "me" or "to me":
(1) "ma", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(a) mai", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice.

My:
"Da mai" also exists as an emphatic or poetic form.
Most possessive adjectives have to agree in gender and number with the noun to which they refer.
"Mes" is the same for the masculine singular and plural.
Note that Surmiran often uses the definite article in combination with possessive pronouns, which the other idioms don't.

Pronouns (possessive):
These have to agree in gender and number with the nouns to which they refer:
il mieu, ils mes
la mia, las mias
(= "mine" or "my one(s)")
"Ils mes" is often used to mean "my family" in the sense of "my dear ones" or "my beloved ones".

Personal pronouns:
This is the emphatic form. The normal form, as used with reflexive verbs, is the same as the word for "me". Note the different masculine and feminine forms.

Pronoun (nominative):
In some cases, "nus" is also used for "us" as well.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "us" or "to us":
 (1) "ans", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(a) nus", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this instance, the word for "we" and "us" is the same.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "us" or "to us":
 (1) "ans", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(a) nus", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this instance, the word for "we" and "us" is the same.

il noss, ils noss

column22:
Personal pronouns:
This is the emphatic form. The normal form, as used with reflexive verbs, is the same as the word for "us". Note the different masculine and feminine forms.

Pronoun (nominative):
All Romansh nouns are either masculine or feminine. "El" (= "he" or "it") is the pronoun used for all masculine nouns.
In some cases, "el" is also used for "him" as well.
The separate word for "it" ("i"/"igl") is only used in impersonal expressions.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "him/it" or "to him/it":
(1) "al", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) el", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "he" and "him" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "him/it" or "to him/it":
 (1) "al", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) el", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "he" and "him" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (nominative):
All Romansh nouns are either masculine or feminine. "Ella" (= "she" or "it") is the pronoun used for all feminine nouns.
In some cases, "ella" is also used for "her" as well.
The separate word for "it" ("i"/"igl") is only used in impersonal expressions.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "her/it" or "to her/it":
 (1) "la" ("l'" before vowels), which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) ella", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "she" and "her" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are two ways of saying "her/it" or "to her/it":
 (1) "la" ("l'" before vowels), which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) ella", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "she" and "her" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (nominative, impersonal)
Since all nouns are either masculine or feminine in Romansh, the pronouns that go with them are "el" (he) or "ella" (she).
"I" ("igl" before vowels) is only used for impersonal expressions (for instance, expressions of time or the weather).

column22:
Personal pronouns:
This is the emphatic form. The normal form, as used with reflexive verbs, is the same as the word for "him"/"it".

Pronoun (nominative):
All Romansh nouns are either masculine or feminine. "Els" (= "they") is the pronoun used for all masculine nouns.
In some cases, "els" is also used for "them" as well.
"Els" is also used for mixtures of masculine and feminine nouns. Where people are involved, however, the modern tendency is to say "ellas ed els".

Personal pronouns:
This is the emphatic form. The normal form, as used with reflexive verbs, is the same as the word for "her"/"it".

Pronoun (nominative):
All Romansh nouns are either masculine or feminine. "Ellas" (= "they") is the pronoun used for all feminine nouns.
In some cases, "ellas" is also used for "them" as well.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are four ways of saying "them" or "to them", depending on whether "them" is masculine (or mixed) or feminine.
The following are the two masculine forms  (1):
"als", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) els", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "they" and "them" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are four ways of saying "them" or "to them", depending on whether "them" is masculine (or mixed) or feminine.
The following are the two masculine forms:
(1) "als", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) els", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "they" and "them" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)
Where people are involved, the modern tendency is to say "(ad) ellas ed (ad) els" and hence to prefer the form after the verb regardless of emphasis. Two pronouns before the verb don't fit in well with the flow of the language.

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are four ways of saying "them" or "to them", depending on whether "them" is masculine (or mixed) or feminine.
The following are the two feminine forms:
(1) "las", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) ellas", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "they" and "them" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Pronoun (accusative/dative):
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun and Surmiran, there are four ways of saying "them" or "to them", depending on whether "them" is masculine (or mixed) or feminine.
The following are the two feminine forms:
(1) "las", which comes BEFORE the verb without any particular emphasis (cf. French, Italian, etc.).
(2) "(ad) ellas", which comes AFTER the verb (as in English) and is more emphatic.
The Engadin idioms follow this practice too, although the emphatic form is rarely used.
Sursilvan has only the latter form, and modern Sutsilvan uses mainly the latter form in practice. In this case, the word for "they" and "them" is the same.
(Remember that all nouns in Romansh are either masculine or feminine.)

Possessive adjectives:
"Dad el(la)s" also exists as an emphatic or poetic form.
Unlike the possessive adjectives for the other persons, the word for "their" in Romansh ("lur") is invariable.

column22:
You:
Saying "you" is much more complicated in Romansh than English. Click "Details" for an explanation.
column23:
Ti, vus, :

SpezialistAs da l'englais stuessan dentant savair ch'i dat vegls citats e proverbis che fan diever dal "ti" obsolet: "thou"/"thee" cun sia furma possessiva "thy"/"thine".
column25:
You/your: 

Saying "you" is much more complicated in Romansh than English.

In standardised Rumantsch Grischun the following distinction is made:
(1) "Ti" is used for talking to ONE relative, close friend, child, animal, etc. 
The normal accusative/dative of "ti" is "ta" and it comes BEFORE the verb.
The emphatic accusative/dative of "ti" is "(a) tai" and it comes AFTER the verb.
The corresponding form of "your" is "tes", "tia" or "tias" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
The corresponding form of "yours" or "your one" is " il tieu", "ils tieus" "la tia" or "las tias" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
(2) "Vus" is always used for the plural and is also when talking to one adult who is not a relative, close friend, etc.
The normal accusative/dative of "vus" is "as" and it comes BEFORE the verb.
The emphatic accusative/dative of "vus" is "(a) vus" and it comes AFTER the verb.
The corresponding form of "your" is "voss", "vossa" or "vossas" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
The corresponding form of "yours" or "your one" is " il voss", "ils voss" "la vossa" or "las vossas" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).

Surmiran follows more or less the same practice as Rumantsch Grischun.

Sursilvan has only the form that comes after the verb, whether emphatic or not.

Sutsilvan mainly uses the form after the verb, whether emphatic or not; the form before the verb still theoretically exists but is little used in the modern language.

Puter and Vallader have an added complication: 
(1) "Tü" is used in the same way as the other versions of Rumantsch.
(2) "Vus" is used as the plural of "tü", i.e. for talking to more than one child, close friend, etc.
(3) The polite way to address one person is to use the third person ("he/him", "she/her"), and the polite way to address several people is to use "they/them". In the written language capital letters are used to distinguish between this "polite you" and the "genuine" third person.

In all versions of Romansh, it is usual to use a capital letter for you/your/yours in letters and e-mails.

The corresponding form of "yours" or "your one" is " il voss", "ils voss" "la vossa" or "las vossas" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).

Surmiran follows more or less the same practice as Rumantsch Grischun.

Sursilvan has only the form that comes after the verb, whether emphatic or not.

Sutsilvan mainly uses the form after the verb, whether emphatic or not; the form before the verb still theoretically exists but is little used in the modern language.

Puter and Vallader have an added complication: 
(1) "Tü" is used in the same way as the other versions of Rumantsch.
(2) "Vus" is used as the plural of "tü", i.e. for talking to more than one child, close friend, etc.
(3) The polite way to address one person is to use the third person ("he/him", "she/her"), and the polite way to address several people is to use "they/them". In the written language capital letters are used to distinguish between this "polite you" and the "genuine" third person.

In all versions of Romansh, it is usual to use a capital letter for you/your/yours in letters and e-mails.

This is the emphatic form. The normal form, as used with reflexive verbs, is the same as the word for "you". Note the different masculine and feminine forms.
For details on how to say "you" in Romansh, set your search mode to "English-Romansh" and enter "you".

column22:
But, however:
In southern/central Graubünden, "però" (which is of Italian origin) is heard very often. Very many Romansh speakers also use the German "aber".

Year:
"Per year" is simply "ad onn".
"In the year 2003" is "l'onn 2003".

column23:
Nulla:
Il term usità american è "zero".
Il term britannic è plitost "nought"
"Nil" vegn duvrà surtut per resultats da sport
Exempel: "Engalterra-Svizra: 4-0" = "England four, Switzerland nil".
Per inditgar in "0" en dumbers da telefon, euv. din ins savens "O" (il bustab!) en englais.
column24: Jau hai ina fitg nauscha nova per tai. = I've got some very bad news for you.

column22:
Gender distinction:
Note the separate feminine form: duas.

Second (1)
2nd.

Second (2):
Unit of time.

Million:
Usual Romansh abbreviation: miu,
column23:
Milliun:
Abreviaziun normala en englais "m" senza spazi ("m" cun spazi vul dir "meter").

column22:
Billion:
"Billion" in the American sense of 1 000 000 000 (now generally adopted throughout the English-speaking world) is "milliarda" in Romansh. The Romansh "billiun" corresponds to an American "trillion" or "thousand billion" (or the older English billion) i.e. 1 000 000 000 000.
column23:
Migliarda/billiun:
Star attent:
Il pled "milliard" n'exista betg en englais normal.
Isotricamain era in billiun englais britannic il medem sco in billiun rumantsch (1 000 000 000 000).
En l'America dal nord signifitgescha in billiun gia dapi ditg il medem sco ina migliarda rumantscha (1 000 000 000). L'adiever britannic sa sviluppa era en quest senn, ma i dat anc surtut glieud veglia en la Gronda Britannia che fa adiever dal billiun en il senn tradiziunal.
Per evitar embrugls, èsi savens meglier da far adiever dals terms segirs "thousand million" u "million million".

column22:
Idiomatic expression:
"Ils da" refers to the inhabitants or citizens of a place.
Example: "ils da Cuira" ("the people of Chur")
column23:
Ils da.../las da...:
En englais na datti nagin'expressiun curta che correspunda a "ils da"/"las da". Ins dovra in'expressiun sco "the inhabitants of..", "the people of...".
Adatg: "those of"/"those from" na tuna betg endretg en englais!

column22:
In, into:
Note that Romansh does not usually make the same distinction between "in" and "into" as in English. However, the southern idioms often use a double-word for "in" i.e. "aint in". This usually means "in(side)" (i.e. no inward movement". If the "aint" is dropped, it can correspond to the English "into".
Note also that in most idioms (but not Rumantsch Grischun) "in" combines with the following definite article to form a single word.
"In" or "on" when applied to a street is "a" in Romansh.

column12: el, ella, ell', els, ellas, egl
column13: el, ella, ell', els, ellas, egl
column22:
Prepositions combined with definite articles in Romansh:
A few common Romansh prepositions are merged with the following definite article to form a single word. The extent of this phenomenon varies from one idiom of the language to another. It occurs least in standardised Rumantsch Grischun.

On (1):
On a horizontal surface, for instance "sin maisa" " = "on the table".

On (2):
On a vertical surface, especially "vi da la paraid" = "on the wall".
column23:
Sin/vi (da)
En englais na fan ins nagina distincziun tranter surfatschas verticalas ed orrizontalas: En domadus cas din ins "on". Ins fa normalmain dentant la differenza tranter "on" (posiziun) ed "onto" (moviment).

column22:
Prepositions combined with definite articles in Romansh:
A few common Romansh prepositions are merged with the following definite article to form a single word. The extent of this phenomenon varies from one idiom of the language to another. It occurs least in standardised Rumantsch Grischun.

Romansh: tar:
This is one of the commonest prepositions in Romansh. Unfortunately, it does not correspond to one particular preposition in English, and the correct translation depends on context.
Its use is very similar to "chez" in French or "bei" in German.
column23:
Tar:
La translaziun endretga da "tar" en englais dependa dal cas concret. Il meglier è dad emprender mintga expressiun per sasezza.

column13: tiel, tiegl, tiels, tiell', tiella, tiellas
column22:
Prepositions combined with definite articles in Romansh:
A few common Romansh prepositions are merged with the following definite article to form a single word. The extent of this phenomenon varies from one idiom of the language to another. It occurs least in standardised Rumantsch Grischun.

column23:
Ortografia normala britannica: favour
Ortografia normala americana: favor

column16: uni, u tgi... ni tgi...
column17: uni, u tgi... ni tgi...

column22:
Very (much):
Note that "fitg" in Romansh can mean either "very" (in combination with another adverb or an adjective) or "very much" (when all by itself).
A very common expression is "graziel fitg" = "thank you very much".
In spoken Romansh, "fitg" is very often placed before the indefinite article, such as "fitg ina buna chaussa", where purists would say "ina fitg buna chaussa". This could be compared very approximately with the English "a very good thing" or "very much of a good thing".
column23:
Fitg:
Nudar la differenza en englais:
"Fitg" sco adverb avant adjectiv è "very". "Fitg" sco adverb isolà è "very much".

column22:
After, afterwards, after that:
In Romansh, the same word is used for "after" and "after that"/"afterwards".

column23: Plural irregular en englais: those

column22:
After, afterwards, after that:
In Romansh, the same word is used for "after" and "after that"/"afterwards".

Who(m):
Romansh makes no distinction between "who" and "whom".

By, until:
In the sense of "by/until a certain time".
Romansh has only one word for both these prepositions: (en)fin.
column23:
Fin, enfin
"By" vegn duvrà per in'activitad che stuess esser terminada fin ad in tschert punct. "Until" (u pli raramain "till") vegn duvrà per ina activitad che cuzza fin ad in tschert punct.
column24:
(1) Guarda dad esser a chasa fin las indesch. =
Be back home by eleven (o'clock).
(2) Ti poss star davent fin las indesch. = You can stay out until eleven (o'clock).

column22:
By, until:
In the sense of "by/until a certain time".
Romansh has only one word for both these prepositions: (en)fin.

column10: in the middle of, in the centre of

column22:
Romansh: "davant"/"avant":
The use of "davant" and "avant" differs considerably between the various versions of Romansh. To keep things simple, the situation for the standardized language, Rumantsch Grischun, can be summarized as follows:
(1) "Davant" is used as a preposition and adverb of place = "in front" / "in front of".
(2) "Avant" is used primarily as a preposition and adverb of time = "before" / "before(hand)".
(3) In certain circumstances, "avant" is used like "davant" - in the same way as "before" is sometimes used spatially in English too ("before your very eyes", etc.).
(4) "Avant" is also used for "ago", but note that the expression of time comes after it  not before as in English.

Romansh: "davant"/"avant":
The use of "davant" and "avant" differs considerably between the various versions of Romansh. To keep things simple, the situation for the standardized language, Rumantsch Grischun, can be summarized as follows:
(1) "Davant" is used as a preposition and adverb of place = "in front" / "in front of".
(2) "Avant" is used primarily as a preposition and adverb of time = "before" / "before(hand)".
(3) In certain circumstances, "avant" is used like "davant" - in the same way as "before" is sometimes used spatially in English too ("before your very eyes", etc.).
(4) "Avant" is also used for "ago", but note that the expression of time comes after it  not before as in English.

By:
By + a mode of transport is "cun" in Romansh.
column23:
Cun:
cun in med da transport è "by".
column24:

Let's go by underground.

column22:
Possession:
There is no equivalent in Romansh to the English possessive in "...'s". You have to use the word for "of". i.e. "da".

(4) "Avant" is also used for "ago", but note that the expression of time comes after it  not before as in English.

Almost, nearly, approximately, etc.:
There are many synonyms for these in Romansh (as in English). Their use is, however not uniform in all versions of the language. The order in which results are displayed ought to correspond roughly to frequency of use.

column22:
In, to:
For movement to a place lower than the speaker or an action at a place lower the speaker, Romansh often uses "giu" rather than "a" or "en", even when a very considerable distance is involved. This is a typical mountain-dweller's perspective.
Examples:
Jau vom giu Turitg = I'm going (down) to Zurich.
Ella stat giu Ginevra = She lives (down) in Geneva.

Only:
"Pir" is used for "only" in the sense of looking forward in time.
Example:
"Jau vegn pir l'emna proxima" = "I'm only coming next week" or "I'm not coming until next week".
"Pir suenter..." ("only after"/"only later") is a very common expression.
column24:
El ha pir sis onns. =
He's only six.

column22:
In, to:
For movement to a place higher up than the speaker or an action at a place higher than the speaker, Romansh often uses "si" rather than "a" or "en", even when a very considerable distance is involved. This is a typical mountain-dweller's perspective.
Examples:
Jau vom si San Murrezzan = I'm going (up) to St. Moritz.
Ella stat si Flem = She lives (up) in Flims.

Next (7):
in the sense of "next to" or "near" a place (preposition).

Romansh verbs (1):

There are several dozen of these, including "vegnir"
To view its full conjugation, click "Details".
The verb "vegnir" is very busy in Romansh.
Its first meaning is "come".
Secondly, it can mean "become" (with daventar" available as an alternative).
Thirdly, it is used as the auxiliary for the passive mood.
Fourthly, it is used to form the normal future tense (in combination with a + the infinitive) in the standardised language and three of the idioms (Puter and Vallader have an inflected future tense. Surmiran has both forms).

column22:
Get:
"Get" has dozens of different meanings in English, and many of them are included in this dictionary. We suggest that you try searching on the basis a fuller expression (get in, get out, get up, etc.) or on the basis of a synonym.
column23:
Englais: "get":
"Get" è in dals verbs pli universals en englais. El vegn duvrà sulet u en cumbinaziun cun in auter pled (normalmain ina preposiziun u in adverb).
Sia muntada pli simpla è "survegnir"/"retschaiver".
El serva savens sco sinonim per "become" (daventar/vegnir):
"Jau vegn vegl" = "I'm getting old".
Quest pledari cuntegna plirs exempels da cumbinaziuns cun "get". Per als vesair in suenter l'auter, endatar "get " e "proxim".
"Get" è irregular:
Passà simpel: got
Particip passà: got / gotten
(Surtut ils americans fan diever da "gotten".)
column24:
I'm getting older. = Jau vegn pli vegl.
I got a bike for my birthday. = Jau hai survegnì in velo per mes anniversari.
She got off the bus and (got) onto the train. = Ella è sortida dal bus ed ida en il tren.
He got freightened by the thunder. = Il tun ha fatg tema ad el.

column22:
Liking, loving, preferring (01):
The adverb "gugent" (which has no direct equivalent in modern English) is used in combination with "avair" for liking people or things and in combination with "far" or many other verbs for liking doing things.
Examples(1):
Jau hai tai gugent = I love you.
(2) Jau fatsch gugent pensums = / I like doing homework.
(3) Jau nod gugent = I like swimming.

Liking, loving, preferring (02):
The adverb "gugent" (which has no direct equivalent in modern English) is used in combination with "avair" for liking people or things and in combination with "far" or many other verbs for liking doing things.

(2) Jau fatsch gugent pensums = / I like doing homework.
(3) Jau nod gugent = I like swimming.

column22:
Time:
The general-purpose word for "time" in Romansh is "temp".
"Ura" (which also means "hour") is used for the time on the clock.
"Peda" is used for having time available to do something.
To have time for something is "avair temp" or "avair peda". But there is a big difference! "Avair temp" simply means having a spare slot in one's diary. "Avair peda" means finding time or making time available for a commitment. (Sometimes the two words are combined: "Avais temp e peda?" (Do you have time for...")
Note the saying: "I dat bain umans che han ina massa temp, mo nagina peda." ("There are people with plenty of time to spare, but never any time to really do anything.")

column24:
(1) Jau sun mo in pau stanchel. =
I'm just a bit tired.
(2) Jau m'hai mo dumandà. = I just wondered.

Thirdly, it is used as the auxiliary for the passive mood.

column23:
Futur en englais:
Il futur normal en il englais pledà è simplamain "'ll". Ozendi scriv'ins er per la plipart "'ll" (a l'excepziun da texts d'ina natira formala).
Noviz(a)s d'englais san emblidar la furma "shall" dal futur e far diever da "will" en tut ils cas.
Spezialistas/spezialists stuessan dentant enconuscher il suandant:
Gia il diever da "will" enstagl da "'ll" dat in tschert pais.
En l'emprima persuna exprima "will" in intent pli ferm che "shall".
En la segunda e terza persuna exprima "shall" bunamain in urden e correspunda a "must" (surtut en texts da leschas).
Adatg: igl è meglier dad evitar quest "shall" dal tuttafatg che dad al duvrar fauss!
Il negativ usità da "will" è "won't".
column25:
VEGNIR 

Preschent: 
jau vegn
ti vegns

Negatives:
With verbs, the usual negative in Rumantsch Grischun is in two parts: "na" (or "n'") before the verb and "betg" after it. In expressions without a verb, the negative is usually just "betg".
Note that some of the idioms use just their equivalent of "betg" after the verb without the "na" before it, whereas others use just one word, "nun", before the verb. These practices are sometimes also encountered in Rumantsch Grischun, but are now considered as wrong.

column22:
Prepositions combined with definite articles in Romansh:
A few common Romansh prepositions are merged with the following definite article to form a single word. The extent of this phenomenon varies from one idiom of the language to another. It occurs least in standardised Rumantsch Grischun.

Reflexive verbs:
Hundreds of these are used regularly in Romansh, and countless others can be made reflexive as required. Often they have a nuance of meaning that is more than "doing something to oneself". Each one is explained individually in this dictionary. The accusative pronoun comes BEFORE the verb (as in French, Italian, etc.). In the infinitive, this is "sa" ("s'" before vowels) in Rumantsch Grischun, Sutsilvan and Surmiran, "se..." or "s'" in Sursilvan and "as" in Puter and Vallader . In Rumantsch Grischun and the majority of the idioms, the pronoun changes according to the person (Rumantsch Grischun, for instance: ma (m'), ta (t'), sa (s'), ans, as, sa (s')). In Sursilvan and Sutsilvan the "se"/"sa"/"s'", which is joined up to the verb, is invariable whatever the person.

column11: Romansh, Romansch, rumantsch, romontsch, rumauntsch, rumàntsch, rumantscah, romontscha, rumauntscha, rumàntscha, Swiss Romansh, Swiss Romance, Rhaeto-Romansh, Rhaeto-Romance, Raeto-Romansh, Raeto-Romance, Reto-Romansh, Reto-Romance
column22:
Romansh:
The language.
Up to a dozen different terms and spellings are to be found in texts written in English. The myPledari compilers have examined these in terms of their frequency and credibility. In agreement with the Lia Rumantscha, we should like to urge everyone to use "Romansh" as the standard English spelling (and to abandon all other forms). As an alternative, it is also acceptable to use the word "Rumantsch" itself in English.
For greater precision in scientific texts, some linguists prefer the term "Swiss Romansh" or "Swiss Romance".
The term "R(h)aeto-Romance" is sometimes limited to Graubünden and sometimes taken to include Dolomitic Ladin and Friulian too.

Ins sa era far adiever dal term "Rumantsch" en englais.

column22:
Idiom:
"Idiom" has maintained a meaning in Romansh that it has more or less lost in modern everyday English. It refers to regional varieties of a language. Romansh has five traditional idioms, which are both spoken and written forms of the language. An idiom is more than a dialect. The five traditional idioms of Romansh can be subdivided into about two dozen (spoken) dialects.
"Idiom" in the usual English sense is best rendered by "expressiun idiomatica".
column23:
Idiom:

Tar na-spezialist(a)s èsi probablamain meglier dad acceptar il pled "dialect" - forsa cun in'agiunta, per exempel: "a Romansh idiom is a bit more than a dialect".

column22:
Swiss cantons (01):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons.
Canton Graubünden joined in 1803, Prior to that it had been known as the State (or Republic) of the Three Leagues (q.v.).
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: GR
Capital: Chur
Official languages: German, Romansh and Italian (the only canton with three official languages)
Population (approx.): 190 000
Surface area: 7105 square kilometres (the largest canton in Switzerland in terms of area)
The use of the French name "Grisons" in English is to be considered obsolete.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda absoluta".

column22:
Acla:
"Acla" is unfortunately one of those words that has different meanings in different parts of Graubünden, reflecting different traditional settlement structures.
In the Engadin and central parts of the canton it is a lodge or cabin providing summer-time accommodation for herdsmen. Some buildings have been converted into holiday cottages.
In Sursevla/Sutsevla it is an area of pastureland a short distance from a village with its own shed or shelter not intended to be lived in.
"Acla" (or its diminutive "acletta") has given rise to numerous place names.

Alpine:
In Romansh, "alpine" is often used as a synonym for "mountainous".

Graubünden and its people:
The traditional form of livestock farming in the Alps is known technically as "transhumance". The animals (and their herdsmen) spend the warmer part of the year at higher altitudes. They are brought back down to the valley during the colder months (which they usually spend indoors). "Ir ad alp" (or "chargiada") is the process of going up to the higher pastures in the spring. In some villages, it is still associated with a traditional ceremony. A much more widespread and a colourful spectacle is the descent back down from the alps in the autumn - the "stgargiada".

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:

Belong:
"Belong" has many synonyms in Romansh. Their use is, however not uniform in all versions of the language. The order in which results are displayed ought to correspond roughly to frequency of use.
myPledari uses the following conventions:

Appetite, hunger:
"Appetit" is often used as a synonym for "hunger" ("fom") in Romansh, especially in the expression "avair appetit" = "to be hungry".
You can wish others an enjoyable meal by saying "bun appetit"!

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (arveglia) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (arvegls) is used for a number counted with precision.

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (arveglia) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (arvegls) is used for a number counted with precision.

Graubünden geography:
A German-speaking village in Prättigau. Its Romansh name is Aschera, but many Romansh speakers also say Schiers.

Animals and genders:
For many species Romansh has separate words for the male and the female, one of which is also used generally for the animal (for mixed genders or when gender is unknown or irrelevant).
Asen = ass or donkey
Asen = male ass or donkey
Asna = female ass or donkey
Romansh does not have separate words for the undomesticated ass and the domesticated donkey. The terms "asen" and "asna" are also used as terms of disrespect for people.

Animals and genders:
For many species Romansh has separate words for the male and the female, one of which is also used generally for the animal (for mixed genders or when gender is unknown or irrelevant).
Asen = ass or donkey
Asen = male ass or donkey
Asna = female ass or donkey
Romansh does not have separate words of the wild ass and the domesticated donkey. The terms "asen" and "asna" are also used as terms of disrespect for people.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda attenta".

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms.

column22:
Swiss cantons (07):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons. Canton Berne joined in 1353.
Increasingly the German spelling "Bern" is also used in English, but we recommend continuing to use "Berne" for the foreseeable future.
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: BE
Capital: Berne
Official languages: German and French
Population: just under a million
Surface area: 3959 square kilometres

column22:
Swiss cantons - adjectives:
For most Swiss cantons, there is a separate adjective in Romansh, which is the same as the name for that canton's citizens, but normally written with a small letter. For certain expressions, the use of "da" (of) is preferred. In English, we either use the noun in an adjectival position or an expression with "of".

column22:
Swiss cantons (05):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons, of which six are half-cantons, created by the division of former larger cantons. The canton of Baselland (or Basel-Landschaft) came into being when Canton Basel was split in 1833.
The spelling "Basle" (pronounced "Baal") used to be used in English; it can now be considered more or less obsolete. The anglicised name of "Basel-Country(side)" sounds very synthetic.
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: BL
Capital: Liestal
Official language: German
Population (approx.): 250 000
Surface area: 517 square kilometres.
Canton Basel originally joined the Swiss Confederation in 1501.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. In this case, the collective form (bratscha) is used for a persons two arms, and the plural in "s" (bratschs) is used in most other senses.

Graubünden geography:
An Italian-speaking valley in the southwest of Graubünden. It borders on the traditionally Romansh-speaking Engadin, and its local dialect ("Bregagliot") includes several Romansh-like features. Its inhabitants are known in Romansh as Bregagliots (m) and Bregagliottas (f).

Graubünden geography:
An Italian-speaking valley in the southwest of Graubünden. It borders on the traditionally Romansh-speaking Engadin, and its local dialect ("Bregagliot") includes several Romansh-like features. Its inhabitants are known in Romansh as Bregagliots (m) and Bregagliottas (f).

Graubünden geography:
An Italian-speaking valley in the southwest of Graubünden. It borders on the traditionally Romansh-speaking Engadin, and its local dialect ("Bregagliot") includes several Romansh-like features. Its inhabitants are known in Romansh as Bregagliots (m) and Bregagliottas (f).

Graubünden geography:

Graubünden geography:
Breil is a Romansh-speaking village in the Surselva, a holiday resort and a skiing centre. Probably better known in English by its German name: Brigels.

Mist, fog:
Modern city dwellers are used to making a distinction between "fog" (which is bad) and "mist" (which is associated more with the countryside and may thus even be considered pleasant). Romansh does not make such a clear distinction. "Tschajera" comes nearest to "fog". "Brentina" is often a rising morning mist, which at some seasons of the year can be quite stunning!

column22:
Brussels:
Romansh speakers usually use the German name "Brüssel" (which sounds the same as its Flemish name "Brussel"). Some prefer the French name "Bruxelles".

Brutal:
"Brutal" is widely used in Romansh (especially in the spoken language) as an adjective expressing any form of extreme.
Examples:
"in pretsch brutal" (a prohibitive price)
"lungurella brutala" (deadly boredom)

Swiss cantons (06):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons, of which six are half-cantons, created by the division of former larger cantons. The half-canton of Basel-Stadt ("Basel-City") came into being when Canton Basel was split in 1833.
The spelling "Basle" (pronounced "Baal") used to be used in English; it can now be considered more or less obsolete.
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: BS
Capital: Basel
Official language: German
Population (approx.): 190 000
Surface area: 37 square kilometres
Canton Basel originally joined the Swiss Confederation in 1501.

Swiss cantons - adjectives:

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "per casualitad".

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda categorica".

Calven Gorge was the scene of a battle fought in 1499, at which the forces of the Three Leagues and their Swiss allies defeated the Habsburgs. It is located on present-day Italian territory, a few kilometres from the border with Graubünden at the bottom of the Val Müstair.

Swiss institutions:
'The cantons are the constituent parts of the Swiss Confederation. There are 26 of them, and they enjoy very extensive political, financial and administrative autonomy.

Chanzlist (m), chanzlista (f).
He or she is in charge of running the public administration of a commune (q.v.), keeping official records, issuing documents, arranging elections and referenda, etc. He/she often has considerable influence. In the smaller communes, it is a part-time post for one person. In the larger communes, the "chanzlist(a)" is in charge of several communal employees.

column22:
Graubünden and its people:
The traditional form of livestock farming in the Alps is known technically as "transhumance". The animals (and their herdsmen) spend the warmer part of the year at higher altitudes. They are brought back down to the valley during the colder months (which they usually spend indoors). "Ir ad alp" (or "chargiada") is the process of going up to the higher pastures in the spring. In some villages, it is still associated with a traditional ceremony. A much more widespread and a colourful spectacle is the descent back down from the alps in the autumn - the "stgargiada".

Graubünden history:
In feudal times, the "chastellan" was the local overlord, the ruler's nominee, who, from his fortified castle, enjoyed virtually unlimited powers. The peasants' struggle against foreign rulers and their stewards was a central element of mediaeval Swiss history (often romanticised later on).

Hello, hi:
The familiar greeting "ciao" has been adopted from Italian and is used very frequently in Romansh. It is used both on meeting and leaving good friends. The Italian spelling is commoner, but the Romansh spelling "tgau" may also be encountered. ("stgavo!" is a regional form used in parts of Surselva.)
Names of countries, regions and the like are generally used in combination with the definite article in Romansh. Thus: la Cipra

column22:
Graubünden institutions:
The "circul" is a grouping of local-authority units (communes).
It is the area that falls within the jurisdiction of a single court. It also corresponds to a constituency for the Graubünden cantonal parliament.
Sometimes a "circul" is entrusted with tasks that small communes cannot carry out rationally by themselves. Currently (2004) the 170 or so communes in Graubünden are grouped into 40 "circuls". You may also encounter the German term "kreis".

column22:
Graubünden geography:
Claustra is the Romansh name for Klosters, a famous Graubünden skiing resort.

Convent, monastery:
"Claustra" is used in Romansh for both convents and monasteries. Local institutions are so much part of traditional Graubünden life, that they are known by everyone and there is no need to be specific!
Müstair has a convent, and Mustér (Disentis) has a monastery.
If ever you need to be more specific, you can say "claustra da mungias" (convent) or "claustra da muntgs/paders" (monastery).
column23:
Claustra:
En englais fan ins adina la distincziun tranter "convent" ( = claustra da mungias) e "monastery" (= claustra da muntgs/paders").

column22:
Barn, hay loft:
In the Engadin, the "tavlo"/"tablà" is the place where hay is kept. Traditionally, this was usually part of a large multi-functional farm building (i.e. a hay loft). On more modern farms, it is often a separate building (i.e. a barn).
In Surselva, for instance, the tradition is different. The "clavau" is always a separate building and not part of the farmhouse. The term may apply to either the whole building (including both the part for stabling animals and the part for storing hay). The term is also applied restrictively to the upper part of the building, i.e. the hay loft.

Pick:
In the sense of picking fruit, etc.

column22:
Light colours:
"Cler" may follow any adjective of colour to mean "light".
Example: brin cler = light brown.

column22:
Expressions with "avair":
Romansh has numerous expressions with "avair" ("have") plus a noun that correspond to English expressions with "be" plus an adjective. In this instance: to "be lucky" is "avair fortuna" or "avair cletg" ("have luck"). In this sense, "cletg" (which is not used in all the idioms) is a synonym of "fortuna". "Fortuna also means "fortune" in the sense of "wealth". "Cletg" means luck in general or a single stoke of luck

Swiss institutions:
Switzerland's territory is divided up into around three thousand local government units, called communes. The "chasa communala" is the commune's central administration. Its size depends on the size of the commune. The corresponding English term would be town hall, city hall, county hall, etc.

column22:
Consultation:
The period of more of less formalised consultation between the government's announcement of its desire/intention to legislate and the actual parliamentary debate and vote on a specific proposal is an important element in the Swiss political system. All stakeholders have the opportunity of airing their view.

Consumption:
(1) "Consum" is the word for the phenomenon of consumption in general.
(2) "Consumaziun" is an individual act of consumption (such as consuming a drink with a meal)..

Writing letters (2):
Endings:
Nearly all letters and e-mails in Romansh have an ending containing the word "salids" (= regards or greetings). There are basically three levels:
Salids = Regards
Salids cordials = Kind regards
Cordials salids = Kindest regards //
column23:
Scriver brevs e postels:
La fin
La furma pli universala ozendi per "salids" è "regards". Ins pudess distinguer trais nivels:
Salids = Regards
Salids cordials = Kind regards
Cordials salids = Kindest regards
I dat er bleras furmlas tradiziunalas en englais cun "yours" plus in adverb. Ma Adatg! Quellas stuessan esser accordadas cun l'introducziun "Dear ".
"Yours" sulet duvr'ins cun in ami u in'amia;
"Yours sincerely" è la furma normala per ina brev ch'entschiava cun "Dear" plus il num;
"Yours faithfully" è la furma normala per ina brev ch'entschiava cun "Dear" plus "Sir" u "Madam"
Tar ses marus/sia marusa pudess'ins scriver "Yours affectionately" sco bleras autras furmlas.
Sco alternativa (surtut americana) san ins metter l'emprim l'adverb ("Sincerely yours,", euv.).

column22:
Romansh idiomatic expression:
This expression is widely used in Romansh. A verb followed by "ad in" plus its own infinitive means to keep on doing something. It can be used with numerous Romansh verbs.
Some of the commonest uses include "crescher ad in crescher" (to keep on growing), "bargir ad in bargir" (cry without stopping), etc.

column22:
Humans, Christians:
Traditionally, some versions of Romansh made no distinction between the word for "human being" and "Christian" and other terms derived from them.
The modern trend (especially in the standardised Rumantsch Grischun) is to use the unambiguous terms "uman(a)" and "crisitian(a)", although "carstgaun(a)" is still the usual term for "human being" in some of the Romansh idioms today.
Note also the use of the small "c" in Romansh: cristian(a).

Transitive and intransitive/reflexive forms of verbs:
The intransitive forms of English verbs often correspond to reflexive verbs in Romansh.

column22:
Swiss institutions:
Traditionally, more or less each village in Switzerland was also a political commune, a civic community and a religious parish. This is still reflected in Romansh today in a somewhat confusing overlap in the use of terms.
In Sursilvan and Sutsilvan, the word "vitg" simply refers to a village as a settlement, whereas "vischnanca" is a village as a political unit (commune).
This distinction is much less clear in the other idioms. "Cumün" in Vallader, for instance refers to a village either as a settlement or as a political/administrative unit (commune).
Even by Swiss standards, the communes in Graubünden enjoy extensive administrative, political and financial autonomy (even sovereignty!). In the political sense, the recommended English translation is "commune". Other translations you may encounter included "community" and "municipality". One objection to the word "community" is that can be even more ambiguous than the others. The big objection to "municipality" is that is represents a city-dweller's perspective of the world, whereas the vast majority of Swiss communes are villages not cities.

"Iert" is a garden used for growing fruit and vegetables.

column22:
Swiss institutions:
The Swiss federal parliament is comprised of two houses. The larger one, the National Council, is elected directly by the people roughly on the basis of proportional representation. The smaller house is called the Council of States. It is also elected by the people, but with two representatives per canton (one each for the six half-cantons).
Use of the terms house of representatives and senate in English is misleading, as are upper house and lower house, given that the two houses are of strictly equal standing.

column22:
Adverbs of place:
Romansh has many precise expressions of absolute and relative position that it is difficult to render concisely in other languages. These are the outcome of the traditional valley-dweller using the valley's topography as a reference system.
"Dadens" is applied to those fields, alps, settlements etc. that are nearer to the centre of the village or valley. "Dadora" is applied to those that are further away.
"Dadens" and "Dadora" (in their regional variants) are parts of many place names in Graubünden.

"Dadens" is applied to those fields, alps, settlements etc. that are nearer to the centre of the village or valley. "Dadora" is applied to those that are further away.
"Dadens" and "Dadora" (in their regional variants) are parts of many place names in Graubünden.

Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates them to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.

column22:
File (1):

Romansh: "davant"/"avant":
The use of "davant" and "avant" differs considerably between the various versions of Romansh. To keep things simple, the situation for the standardized language, Rumantsch Grischun, can be summarized as follows:
(1) "Davant" is used as a preposition and adverb of place = "in front" / "in front of".
(2) "Avant" is used primarily as a preposition and adverb of time = "before" / "before(hand)".
(3) In certain circumstances, "avant" is used like "davant" - in the same way as "before" is sometimes used spatially in English too ("before your very eyes", etc.).
(4) "Avant" is also used for "ago", but note that the expression of time comes after it  not before as in English.

Romansh synonyms:
"Partir" and "ir davent" can be used as synonyms in Romansh, just like "leave" and "go away" in English.

column22:
Romansh verbs (1):
Irregular verbs:
There are several dozen of these, including "vegnir"
To view its full conjugation, click "Details".
The verb "vegnir" is very busy in Romansh.
Its first meaning is "come".
Secondly, it can mean "become" (with daventar" available as an alternative).
Thirdly, it is used as the auxiliary for the passive mood.
Fourthly, it is used to form the normal future tense (in combination with a + the infinitive) in the standardised language and three of the idioms (Puter and Vallader have an inflected future tense. Surmiran has both forms).

Many Romansh adjectives are used as nouns. Just put an article in front of them. There is no need for a word corresponding to the English "one".
Example:
Il davos, la davosa = the last one.
Months are written with small letters in Romansh. "In December" is simply "il december".

To order drinks (especially wine) by the carafe in Switzerland, one stipulates a number of "decis" (i.e. tenths of litres).

column22:
Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda definitiva".

column22:
Hating, disliking, detesting (1):
The following can be considered as synonyms in Romansh: "odiar", "detestar", "hassegiar"/"hassiar" (whereby the last of these is not used in all the idioms).
The negative "na far betg gugent" is often used just like the English "don't like".

Hating, disliking, detesting (2):
The following can be considered as synonyms in Romansh: "odiar", "detestar", "hassegiar"/"hassiar" (whereby the last of these is not used in all the idioms).
The negative "na far betg gugent" is often used just like the English "don't like".

Hating, disliking, detesting (3):
The following can be considered as synonyms in Romansh: "odiar", "detestar", "hassegiar"/"hassiar" (whereby the last of these is not used in all the idioms).
The negative "na far betg gugent" is often used just like the English "don't like".

Hating, disliking, detesting (4):
The following can be considered as synonyms in Romansh: "odiar", "detestar", "hassegiar"/"hassiar" (whereby the last of these is not used in all the idioms).
The negative "na far betg gugent" is often used just like the English "don't like".

Hating, disliking, detesting (5):
One of the commonest ways of saying we don't like something in Romansh is to say we do it unwillingly.

Hating, disliking, detesting (6):
This regional expression is roughly the equivalent to the English "getting on someone's wick/goat".

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (detta) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (dets) is used for a number counted with precision.

Day:
"By day" is "da di".

Hello, hi:
The greeting "bun di" is used on meeting people up until around midday/lunchtime. After that "buna saira" is used.
Learners often give themselves away with their first utterance in Romansh when they say "bun di" in the afternoon"!
In the Engadin "Allegra" is used at any time of the day.

Hello, hi:
"Allegra!" (or "Allegramaing!") is about the commonest way of saying "hello "in the Engadin. Traditionally it was hardly used elsewhere. Nowadays, however, people in the rest of Switzerland consider it to be almost synonymous with Romansh itself!

column22:
Fairy, fairy story:
More than 2000 fairy stories, fables and the like, which have been handed down orally from generation, to generation exist in the Romansh language. This is one of the richest collection in Europe and even in the world. Interestingly, another European language with a similar number of traditional fairy stories is Dolomitic Ladin (Ladino), which is closely related to Swiss Romansh. The only comparable collections anywhere else in the world are in some of the languages of India.

"Adisar" is used for getting someone (or something) else used to something.

Graubünden geography:
A large village about 10 km to the west of Chur. It is the home of Graubünden's biggest industrial operation the "Ems-Werke" (Fabrica da Domat). Its Romansh traditions are still very strong, although the number of native speakers are only a small proportion of the inhabitants. "Romonsch da Domat" is not one of the traditional written versions of the language. Sursilvan is used as the written language, although the spoken language has numerous features closer to Sutsilvan.

column22:
Mrs. Ms.
Generally speaking, Romansh women are less insistent on eliminating the distinction between "dunna" and "giuvna" than English speakers have been with "Mrs." and "Miss".
Romansh does not have a neutral term corresponding to the English "Ms."
Nowadays, older woman are generally addressed as "dunna" irrespective of their marital status.
column23:
Dunna, signura / giuvna:
Tradiziunalmain devi en englais la medema distincziun sco en rumantsch: "Mrs." = "dunna" e "Miss" = "giuvna". La furma "Miss" è bunamain svanida da l'englais modern (sco "Fräulein" en tudestg). Il pli savens fan ins adiever dal term "Ms.". "Ms." san ins er duvrar per ina dunna maridada. Pliras dunnas maridadas (surtut pli veglias) prefereschan adina il term "Mrs.".

column22:
Woman, wife:
"Dunna" means either "woman" or "wife". Romansh speakers often simply say "la dunna", which is not as pejorative as "the wife" can be in English.
"Consorta" (="spouse") is a more elegant alternative.
column23: Plural englais: wives

column22:
Woman, wife:
"Dunna" means either "woman" or "wife". Romansh speakers often simply say "la dunna", which is not as pejorative as "the wife" can be in English.
"Consorta" (="spouse") is a more elegant alternative.
"Dunna" is the neutral word for "woman" and may sometimes be better translated as "lady". "Femna", on the other hand, generally has negative connotations, except in Surselva (although, even there, there is now a tendency to avoid it in polite conversation).

Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda effectiva".

Graubünden geography:
The Engadin derives its name from the river Inn ("En" in Romansh).
It rises in Lai dal Lughin, 16 km (10 miles) southwest of St. Moritz). It flows through the Upper and Lower Engadin and on into Austria, where it gives its name to the Tyrolean capital, Innsbruck (Puntina in Romansh). It continues into Bavaria, Germany, and eventually joins the Danube at Passau. Its total length in 510 km (317 miles).
The French spelling "Engadine" is sometimes still found in English too.

column22:
Homesickness, longing for home:
A longing to be back home is at the heart of Romansh feelings and is reflected in numerous writings and songs.
Asking travellers if they long to be home or if they feel homesick is almost as much a part of Romansh conversation as is the weather in the English-speaking world!
The subject of "encreschadetgna" is not new. It has roots deep in history. In the poor regions of Romansh-speaking Graubünden the rural economy was only ever able to support a limited population, and many people simply had to go elsewhere for a period of time or even for good to find the merest of livelihoods.
Note the verbal expression "Laschas ti encrescher?" ("Do you feel homesick?" - literally: "do you allow a feeling of homesickness to arise?")
(See also the note on "swallow" or "randulin(a)".)

Set up:
(1) "endrizzar" or "drizzar en" is the commonest way of setting "set up", etc. in Romansh.

Guess:
The expression "I guess", which is often used at the start of an English sentence more to fill space than because it has any real meaning, can simply be left out in Romansh. The adverb, "magari", which Romansh has borrowed for Italian, is similar in its function.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. In this case, the collective form (detta) is used for all the fingers of a hand, and the plural in "s" (dets) is used in most other senses.

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (fava) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (favs) is used for a number counted with precision.

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (fava) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (favs) is used for a number counted with precision.

column22:
Favugn, föhn:
The "föhn" or "favugn" is a hot downwind. This weather phenomenon is caused when a wet wind cools slowly as it ascends the Alps, losing its precipitation, and then warms up again much faster as it descends in a drier state. It is blamed for all sorts of disorders affecting people and animals.
The usual Romansh expression is "i trai favugn" (= "there's a föhn blowing").
Complication:
The word "föhn/favugn" is sometimes also used in Romansh (and German) to mean "hair dryer"!
column23:
Favugn:
In fenomen sco il favugn n'exista betg en grondas parts dal mund anglofon. Igl è alura savens necessari d'al explitgar a visitadras ed a visitaders en las Alps (vesair p.ex. il text curt da la remartga englaisa).

column22:
Swiss institutions:
This is the building in the federal capital (Berne) that accommodates the two houses of Switzerland's federal parliament.

Swiss institutions:
The Swiss Federal Council (which has seven members) has two functions:
(1) It is comparable to the cabinet (government) of other countries. Each or its members is in charge of one or more "departments" (the equivalent of ministries".
(2) It is the collective head of state.
In practice, the presidential duties are generally performed by the Federal President. Each year, a new Federal President is elected from amongst the Federal Councillors by the two houses of the Federal Parliament voting together. The office rotates very roughly as a function of the Federal Councillors' seniority, and the longer-standing ones may well be elected for a second term a few years after their first one.

(2) It is the collective head of state.
In practice, the presidential duties are generally performed by the Federal President. Each year, a new Federal President is elected from amongst the Federal Councillors by the two houses of the Federal Parliament voting together. The office rotates very roughly as a function of the Federal Councillors' seniority, and the longer-standing ones may well be elected for a second term a few years after their first one.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (feglia) is used for an indefinite number (i.e. "foliage"), and the plural in "s" (fegls) is used for a number counted with precision.

column22:
Swiss customs:
The Swiss, in common with many other European peoples, have the custom of wishing one another an enjoyable meal before starting to eat. In Romansh, the usual expression is "bun appetit"!
"Avair appetit" (literally "to have appetite") is a common way of saying that one is hungry.
column23:
Bun appetit:
Sa giavischar in bun appetit avant da mangiar n'ha betg la medema tradiziun en pajais anglofons sco en la gronda part da l'Europa. En famiglia u tar amis na din ins anc oz plitost nagut. En ina situaziun pli formala san ins dir "Enjoy your meal!" u simplamain "Enjoy!" (tendenza moderna). Ins sa er far diever da l'expressiun franzosa "bon appétit!". En famiglias fitg religiusas remplazza ina pitschna oraziun il "bun appetit".

column22:
Expressions with "avair":
Romansh has numerous expressions with "avair" ("have") plus a noun that correspond to English expressions with "be" plus an adjective. In this instance: to "be lucky" is "avair fortuna" or "avair cletg" ("have luck"). In this sense, "cletg" (which is not used in all the idioms) is a synonym of "fortuna". "Fortuna also means "fortune" in the sense of "wealth". "Cletg" means luck in general or a single stoke of luck

(3) Phrase = ina part d'ina frasa senza in verb.
"Construction" vegn duvrà per mintga furma da structura grammatica.

Swiss cantons - adjectives:
For most Swiss cantons, there is a separate adjective in Romansh, which is the same as the name for that canton's citizens, but normally written with a small letter. For certain expressions, the use of "da" (of) is preferred. In English, we either use the noun in an adjectival position or an expression with "of".

column22:
Germany:
Whereas the standardised language has opted for "Germania", the form "Tiaratudestga" / "Tearatudestga" / "Tera tudestga" is the one usually used in the three more northerly Romansh idioms.
The adjective is, however, "tudestg" throughout.
"German" in Romansh corresponds to the English "Germanic".

Nationalities, etc.
Generally the adjective is the same as the noun in Romansh. There is no need for a word "man" or "woman".
The usual Romansh word for German is "tudestg"; "germanais" is sometimes used as an alternative in Puter and Vallader.
column24: El è tudestg. = He's (a) German.

column22:
Germanisms in Romansh:
The German word "schon" is often used in the spoken language.
It is added not really in the sense of "already", but in the sense of doing something easily: "quai sai jau schon far" = "I can to that, no problem".

column22:
Romansh verbs (9):
Verbs with the "-el" ending in their first person singular:
 "Giaschair" is one of these. To view its full conjugation, click "Details". 
In Rumantsch Grischun, the first-person singular normally has no ending. Whenever the verb stem ends in a palatalised consonant, a consonant cluster or an "i", "...el" is added.
In Sursilvan, most verbs have this ending.

column22:
Adverbs of place:
Romansh has many precise expressions of absolute and relative position that it is difficult to render concisely in other languages. Many of these reflect the traditional valley-dweller's use the valley's topography as a reference system.
"Giusum", "giudim" or "giufuns" is the lowest point in the village or the land belonging to it.

column22:
Swiss geography:
The Jura is a mountainous area in the north of Switzerland stretching into France which has given its name to a geological period. It is also the name of one of the Swiss cantons.
Note that, despite ending in an "a", "Giura" is a masculine noun.

Swiss cantons (11):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons.
Canton Jura is Switzerland's newest canton. It was created in 1979, when it separated from Canton Berne.
Here are a few statistics:
Official abbreviation: JU
Capital: Delémont
Official language: French
Population (approx.): 70 000
Surface area: 839 square kilometres
Note that, despite ending in an "a", "Giura" is a masculine noun.

column22:
Young lady, Miss:
Generally speaking, Romansh women are less insistent on eliminating the distinction between "dunna" and "giuvna" than English speakers have been with "Mrs." and "Miss".
Romansh does not have a neutral term corresponding to the English "Ms."
Nowadays, older woman are generally addressed as "dunna" irrespective of their marital status. "Giuvna" in Romansh does not have the same negative connotations as "Miss" in modern English or "Fräulein" in German.
column23:
Dunna, signura / giuvna:
Tradiziunalmain devi en englais la medema distincziun sco en rumantsch: "Mrs." = "dunna" e "Miss" = "giuvna". La furma "Miss" è bunamain svanida da l'englais modern (sco "Fräulein" en tudestg). Il pli savens fan ins diver dal term "Ms.". "Ms." san ins er duvrar per ina dunna maridada. Pliras dunnas maridadas (surtut pli veglias) prefereschan adina il term "Mrs.".

column22:
Ice (cream):
Romansh usually makes no distinction between "ice" and "ice cream".
The term "glacé" (cf. French: glace) is also frequently used for "ice (cream)" in Switzerland.

People:
"Pievel" is used in the sense of a "population" or the "populace".
"Il pievel rumantsch" = "the Romansh people"
"Glieud" (which is grammatically singular and semantically plural) is used more in the sense of people in general.
"La glieud di che..." = "People say that..."

Snail:
Purists prefer the indigenous term "glimaja", but "schnec" is actually used more, especially in the north of Graubünden.

Linen:
"Made of linen" is "da glin"
Days of the week are usually written with a small letter in Romansh. "On Monday" is simply "glindesdi". "On Mondays" is "il glindesdi".

column22:
Graubünden geography:
Ilanz/Glion is the largest town in Surselva (the first town on the Rhine). Ilanz has traditionally insisted on using German as its official language, although it has a large Romansh community living in it and the majority of the villages around it are Romansh-speaking.

Light(1):
"Glisch" is used for "light" in the sense of the physical phenomenon.

Pre-metric units:
The pound as a unit of mass is not used in modern Switzerland.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. In this case, the collective form (gnerva) is the usual plural, and the plural in "s" (gnervs) is only used when specific nerves are referred to.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (grippa) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (grips) is used for a number counted with precision.

column22:
Graubünden institutions / Swiss institutions:
Graubünden (in common with most Swiss cantons) used to use the term "big council" ("Cussegl grond") for its parliament and "little council" for its government. Whereas the former term has been maintained, the government is now called "regenza".
The Graubünden cantonal parliament normally meets in plenary for four weeks a year (spaced out roughly evenly), and the job of its elected members (deputies) is thus only part-time.
Names of countries, regions and the like are generally used in combination with the definite article in Romansh. Thus: la Gronda Britannia

Liking, loving, preferring (06):
The English expression "keen on" or "keen to" is best rendered in Romansh with a sentence using the adverb "gugent" (q.v.).
Examples:
"I'm keen on football" = "Jau hai gugent il ballape".
"I'm not (very) keen on my French teacher" = "jau nun hai (insumma betg) gugent mes magister da franzos."
As stronger alternatives, it is also possible to use adjectives such as "entusiasmà" or "intgntà".

column23:
Englais "keen":
L'adiever da "keen" en englais è limità a tscherts champs (sco persunas, bavrondas/victualias, sports e activitads dal temp liber, ...).
En blers cas correspunda ina construcziun cun "keen" en englais ad ina construcziun cun "gugent" en rumantsch.
La furma negativa, surtut cun "very" vegn atgnamain duvrada pli savens che la furma positiva.

column22:
Garden:
Romansh has two words for garden.
"Curtin" is the plot of land around a residential property, which may or may not be fenced in. In the countryside, especially, it may include fruit trees.
"Iert" is a garden used for growing fruit and vegetables.

Graubünden geography:
Today, Igis-Landquart is the third most populous commune in Graubünden (approx. 7500 inhabitants) after Chur and Davos. The village of Igis (originally called Eigias in Romansh) was founded by Romansh speakers, but has been predominantly German-speaking for about 500 years. The advent of the railways changed everything. A totally new settlement called Landquart was built on formerly inhospitable marshland, and the Rhaetian Railway established its central depot there.

Instanza (1):
This word is used the same as in English for an instance (occurrence) of something or an official instance, such as a court. It has the additional meaning of an officially submitted document or the like. The English "for instance", on the other hand, has to be translated as "per exempel".

column22:
Romansh: Insumma:
"Insumma" is one of about a dozen adverbs popularly used in Romansh to give sentences a particular flavour (especially interrogative and negative sentences). It may be the equivalent of "actually", "really", "at all", "in the finally analysis", etc. The essence of "insumma" is often best rendered in English by an appropriate tone of voice rather than a particular expression.

Jauer:
The Jauers (m) and Jauras (f) are the Romansh-speaking inhabitants of the Val Müstair (Münstertal). The corresponding adjective is the same, only with a small letter. Spoken Jauer is clearly a distinctive form of Romansh. It is not, however, usually regarded as a separate idiom, since it is not a traditional written form. Jauer speakers write Vallader.

Jauer:
The Jauers (m) and Jauras (f) are the Romansh-speaking inhabitants of the Val Müstair (Münstertal). The corresponding adjective is the same, only with a small letter. Spoken Jauer is clearly a distinctive form of Romansh. It is not, however, usually regarded as a separate idiom, since it is not a traditional written form. Jauer speakers write Vallader.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms.
In the case of "lain", the normal plural in "s" is rarely used. The collective form ("laina") is used frequently for "timber" or "felled trees".
column23:

L'indstria da laina è "timber industry".

column22:
Let's
"Vulain" is the "we" form of "vulair" (to want). In the sense of "let's", the word for us ("nus") is usually omitted. "Vulain" is nearly always shortened to "lain" in the spoken language. It is followed by an infinitive.
Examples:
Lain ir = let's go.
Lain gentar = Let's have lunch.
