Romansh verbs (2):
Regular verbs with an infinitive in "-ar":
"Laschar" is one of these. To view its full conjugation, click "Details".
"Lascher" + a second verb in the infinitive is used in the sense of "to let something be done", "to cause something to be done", "to have something done" (cf. French, Italian, German, etc.).
In the spoken language, the first syllable, "la", is often omitted.

column22:
Homesickness, longing for home:
A longing to be back home is at the heart of Romansh feelings and is reflected in numerous writings and songs.
Asking travellers if they long to be home or if they feel homesick is almost as much a part of Romansh conversation as is the weather in the English-speaking world!
The subject of "encreschadetgna" is not new. It has roots deep in history. In the poor regions of Romansh-speaking Graubünden the rural economy was only ever able to support a limited population, and many people simply had to go elsewhere for a period of time or even for good to find the merest of livelihoods.
Note the verbal expression "Laschas ti encrescher?" ("Do you feel homesick?" - literally: "do you allow a feeling of homesickness to arise?")
(See also the note on "swallow" or "randulin(a)".)

Swiss history:
Before it became part of the Swiss Confederation in 1803, Graubünden used to be known as the State of the Three Leagues or the Republic of the Three Leagues.
Leagues, which were basically defensive alliances, have played an important part in Swiss history.

Romansh: Lia Rumantscha:

Graubünden history:
The name Graubünden was coined for the canton when it joined the Swiss Confederation in 1803. Before that, from 1471 onward, it had been known as the (Free) State of the Three Leagues (or the Republic of the Three Leagues). The three leagues were: the League of God's House, the Grey League and the League of the Ten Jurisdictions.

column22:
Swiss institutions:
For Swiss citizens, the "place of citizenship" is not the same as either the place of birth or the place of residence. Traditionally, it was the place where Swiss citizens had most of their rights and duties. For instance, it was the community that would look after them if they fell on hard times. In modern times, it has lost much of this role in practice, although it is has to be indicated on most official forms (where other nationalities indicate their place of birth). For numerous families with long-standing ties with a particular location, it remains of considerable emotional importance.

column22:
Language (1):
In Sursilvan, Sutsilvan and Surmiran, "linguatg" is the normal word for language, whereas Puter and Vallader use "lingua". In Puter and Vallader, "linguach" is a poetic alternative (cf. "favella").

Language (2):
"Favella" is more of a poetic term for "language", suggesting a strong emotional attachment. It is used by Romansh speakers virtually only with reference to their own language.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "en il rom da la linguistica".

Sausage:
You may encounter the expression (adopted from German) "i va per la liongia". It means something like "this is what really matters" or "this is the crucial issue".

Expressions with "avair":
Romansh has numerous expressions with "avair" ("have") plus a noun that correspond to English expressions with "be" plus an adjective. In this instance: to "be bored" is "avair lungurella" ("have boredom"). A stronger adjective for "bored" is "unfis" (= fed up").

Swiss cantons - adjectives:
For most Swiss cantons, there is a separate adjective in Romansh, which is the same as the name for that canton's citizens, but normally written with a small letter. For certain expressions, the use of "da" (of) is preferred. In English, we either use the noun in an adjectival position or an expression with "of".

En bunamain tut ils cas na datti nagin num englais per las burgaisas ed ils burgais dals chantuns svizzers. Tut tenor fan ins adiever d'in'expressiun cun "of" u dal num dal chauntun sco adjectiv.

column22:
Graubünden geography:
An Upper-Engadin village.

Romansh: magari:
This expression, which Romansh has borrowed from Italian, is basically a "filler" with no strong meaning of its one. There are numerous ways of (more or less) rendering it in English. It can often be omitted or simply lead to a change in voice.

Guess:
The expression "I guess", which is often used at the start of an English sentence more to fill space than because it has any real meaning, can simply be left out in Romansh. The adverb, "magari", which Romansh has borrowed for Italian, is similar in its function.
column23:
Englais: "guess"
Sia muntada tradiziunala è "engiavinar". Ozendi vegn "I guess" duvrà (surtut en englais american) per entschaiver ina frasa d'ina moda precauta. I correspunda in zic a l'inserziun d'in "magari" en ina construcziun rumantscha.

Englais: "I figure":
Surtut en englais american entschaiv'ins savens ina frasa cun "I figure". Quest'expressiun è bunamain adina senz'atgna muntada e serva simplamain sco ditga. En rumantsch schess ins tranter auter "magari".
Far adatg al "of" en englais en expressiuns sco "a glass of milk" (in magiel latg).

column22:
Eat:
In standardised Rumantsch Grischun, "mangiar" is used for people eating and "magliar" for animals eating. When applied to people "magliar" means eating badly ("eating like a pig"). Some of the Romansh idioms do not make this distinction (especially Sursilvan) and "magliar" is the usual term for human beings.

column22:
Two-part negatives:
These are common in some forms of Romansh, especially the standardised written language, Rumantsch Grischun.
"Namai" means "never", whereas "mai" by itself means "ever" (especially in questions).

Two-part negatives:
These are common in some forms of Romansh, especially the standardised written language, Rumantsch Grischun.
"Namai" means "never", whereas "mai" by itself means "ever" (especially in questions).

Graubünden geography:
A German-speaking village in the northeast of Graubünden borders (in the Bündner Herrschaft). Famous for its wine and as the central setting of the Heidi story.

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (maila) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (mails) is used for a number counted with precision.

It is a feature of traditional Graubünden cuisine (especially in Surselva) for savoury foods (such as noodles) to be combined with sweet foods (especially puréed apples or other fruit).

column22:
Bad (2):
Romansh has several different words for "bad" and its synonyms.
"Mal" is used for feeling bad, ill, sorry, etc. ("mal" is usually used in combination with the verb "star").

Expressions with "avair":
When something hurts us in Romansh, we say we have pain: "avair mal".

Apologising:
There are various ways of apologising in Romansh.
"Star mal" is one of the commonest in the northern parts of Graubünden. Note that it is the verb "star" and not "esser" that is used in this expression.
In the Engadin "star mal"/"ster mel" means "feel unwell".

Apologising:
The usual way of saying "I'm sorry" in the northern parts of Graubünden is "Jau stun mal",...
In the south, the usual expression is "quai am displascha",// myPledari uses the following conventions:
----- = No equivalent term exists.
(...) = Term exists but is not the usual one.

Aches and pains (1):
"Avair mal" is used for feeling a pain in a part of the body.

column22:
Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "mal".

Unfortunately, unluckily:
Romansh has many different expressions for "unfortunately" or "unluckily". They are not all used to the same extent in all the idioms.
myPledari uses the following conventions:
----- = No equivalent term exists;
(...) = Term exists but is not the usual one.

column22:
Transitive and intransitive/reflexive forms of verbs:
The intransitive forms of English verbs often correspond to reflexive verbs in Romansh.
"Maridar" is used for one person marrying another or for an official, a priest, etc. declaring two people to be married.
The reflexive "sa maridar" is sometimes used for two people getting married to one another.

Transitive and intransitive/reflexive forms of verbs:
The intransitive forms of English verbs often correspond to reflexive verbs in Romansh.
"Maridar" is used for one person marrying another or for an official, a priest, etc. declaring two people to be married.
The reflexive "sa maridar" is used for two people getting married to one another.

Animals and genders:
For many species Romansh has separate words for the male and the female, one of which is also used generally for the animal (for mixed genders or when gender is unknown or irrelevant).

Mastgel da l'anda = drake

Friends:
"Ami" is used for any friend that happens to be male and also specifically for "boy friend". The context often makes it clear, but not always. Be careful!

column22:
Romansh: medemamain:
"Medemamain" has two main meanings:
(1) equally
Example: Tut las tratgas èn medemamain bunas = All the dishes are equally good.
(2) "same to you" (returning a wish, greeting, etc.)
Example:
"Bun appetit!" "Medemamain!" = "Enjoy your meal!" "Enjoy yours too!"

Romansh: medemamain:

Valur media:
En il senn scientific (q.v.d. quantitativ) è il term correct en englais "mean". "Average" è il term qualitativ (q.v.d. ch'ins na sa betg mesirar). En il linguatg da mintgadi vegn "mean" dentant strusch duvrà ed ins di "average" en il senn qualitativ e quantitativ.

"Meglier" or "meglra" without an article generally means "better" and with the definite article "best".

Menu:

column22:
Merda (1):
"Merda" has two meanings in Romansh.
One is "excrement" (cf. French: "merde").
It is also used as a general term for rubbish or things that are dirty or have little or no value.
It is to be considered less strong than the English "crap".

Merda (2):
"Merda" has two meanings in Romansh.
One is "excrement" (cf. French: "merde").
It is also used as a general term for rubbish or things that are dirty or have little or no value.
It is to be considered less strong than the English "crap".
column23:
Merda:
Far adatg cun il pled "shit" en englais, che vegn considerà bler pli vulgar che "Scheisse" en tudestg e ch'ins stuess alura normalmain evitar!
En cas da dubi san ins far adiever d'in eufomissem "dirt".
"Crap" è in term cun ina fermezza tranter ils dus auters. Sco "merda" en Rumantsch, vegn el duvrà tant en il senn litteral sco en il senn figurativ.

column22:
Midnight:
"At midnight" is "a mesanotg".
In numerous traditional Romansh expressions, "mesanotg" also means "north".
In modern Switzerland, the twenty-four-hour format is the usual way of writing times. In the spoken language, the twelve-hour clock is still widely used.
00:00 = 12:00 a.m.
column23:

L'ura scritta:
Tenor la norma internaziunala/europaica stuessan er ils pajais anglofons far diever da la furma cun 24 uras. Ins chatta dentant surtut en America dal nord savens la veglia furma (00:00 = 12:00 midnight u 12 a.m.) (12 p.m. è mezdi!).
En il linguatg pledà din ins:
midnight,
twelve (o'clock), u
twelve a.m.

column22:
Romansh: Mesiras:
"Mesiras" in the plural has a very particular traditional meaning.
In the summer, all the farmers of a village take their herds of cattle up to high mountain common land pastures. The cows' milk is generally all collected together for cheese-making. To know what each farmer's share should be, all the cows are "calibrated" according to their milk yield on a particular day. This ceremony is known as "Mesiras".

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (miraglia = walls, masonry) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (mirs) is used for a number that has been counted with precision.

column22:
Sea:
"Mar", the simple word for "sea" is feminine in Rumantsch Grischun, Sursilvan, Sutsilvan and Surmiran, but masculine in Puter and Vallader. Many of the actual names of seas are, however, masculine in all versions of Romansh.

Apple juice, cider:
"Most" is the commonest word in Switzerland for apple juice, whether fermented or not. You may well be served with cider, unless you stress "most dultsch". Similarly, in parts of Graubünden, a "cider dultsch" is not sweet cider but straightforward, unfermented apple juice.

The Romansh term "barbis" is used for both cat's whiskers and for a moustache with a similar shape.

Graubünden geography:
Mustér (German: Disentis) is one of the biggest predominantly Romansh-speaking villages in Surselva. It is an important winter-sports resort and the railway interchange between the Rhaetian Railway and the Matterhorn-Gotthard Railway. The massive monastery (which also operates a school) dominates the village.

Come here:
"Nà", an adverb corresponding to the English "hither", is also used as the familiar imperative of "vegnir" (come) and to mean "coming from" ("in vent nà dal sid" = "a southerly wind").

Two-part negatives:
Some versions of Romansh require a two-part negative: a "na" before the verb and "nagin(a)" after it.

Two-part negatives:

"Crazy about..." is "nar da...".

column22:
Birth (1):

Swiss institutions:
For Swiss citizens, the "place of citizenship" is not the same as either the place of birth or the place of residence. Traditionally, it was the place where Swiss citizens had most of their rights and duties. For instance, it was the community that would look after them if they fell on hard times. In modern times, it has lost much of this role in practice, although it is has to be indicated on most official forms (where other nationalities indicate their place of birth). For numerous families with long-standing ties with a particular location, it remains of considerable emotional importance.

Romansh: "Navair":
"Navair?" is a short negative question following a positive statement. It is used invariable regardless of the preceding verb or tense. For instance, it can mean "aren't you?", "wasn't I?", "won't she be?", etc.

column22:
NEAT, Port'Alpina:
"NEAT" is the biggest and most expensive engineering project in Switzerland's history. New tunnels through the Alps are to enhance railway capacity enormously, cut journey times significantly and (hopefully) reduce the volume of road traffic.
The Gotthard Base Tunnel is to pass under Tujetsch (the highest part of Romansh-speaking Surselva) at a depth of 800 m below the village of Sedrun.
"Port'Alpina" is the name given to a proposal to build an underground station.

Verbs with a vowel change in some of their parts and the "-el" ending in their first person singular:
"Duvrar" is one of these. To view its full conjugation, click "Details".
In Rumantsch Grischun, the first-person singular normally has no ending. Whenever the verb stem ends in a palatalised consonant, a consonant cluster or an "i", "...el" is added. There are certain border-line cases, such as this one, in which the addition of the "-el" ending is optional.
In Sursilvan, most verbs have this ending.

column22:
Adjectives used as adverbs.
Romansh has countless adjectives that are also used as adverbs without needing the "main" ending.
"Negativ" is one of them.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda negativa".

Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates them to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. In this case, the collective form (ogna) is used for a stand of alder trees, etc., and the plural in "s" (ogns) is used for a number of trees counted with precision.

Netherlands / Holland:
Whereas it is a sign of ignorance, discourtesy or worse to say "Holland" in English, when you really mean "the Netherlands", there is no natural way of making this distinction in Romansh. You could try saying "Ollanda en il senn da tut il pajais" as opposed to "Ollanda en il senn da las duas provinzas Ollanda dal nord e Ollanda dal sid". Alternatively you could write the local name in brackets: "Ollanda (Nederland)" - "Ollanda (Noord- en Zuidholland)"
"Pajais bass" tends to correspond more to the historic use of "the Low Countries" (including Flanders, etc.).
Names of countries, regions and the like are generally used in combination with the definite article in Romansh. Thus: l'Ollanda.
column23:
Ollanda:
En Rumantsch na datti betg ina distincziun natirala tranter "Nederland" (l'entir pajais) e "Holland" (duas da sias nov provinzas). En englais stuess ins far adatg a questa differenza!

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. In this case, the collective form (ossa) is used for a set of bones such as a skeleton, and the plural in "s" (os) is used for a number counted with precision.

Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates the points of the compass to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.

column22:
Fairy, fairy story:
More than 2000 fairy stories, fables and the like, which have been handed down orally from generation to generation, exist in the Romansh language. This is one of the richest collections in Europe and even in the world. Interestingly, another European language with a similar number of traditional fairy stories is Dolomitic Ladin (Ladino), which is closely related to Swiss Romansh. The only comparable collections anywhere else in the world are in some of the languages of India.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda particulara".

Graubünden cuisine:
This is a traditional speciality produced at Carnival time, not only in Graubünden but in many parts of Switzerland. Patlaunas are very thin, sweetened, wafer-like biscuits with a diameter of around 20 cm. They are deep-fried, which makes them crinkly and brittle. They are usually broken into small pieces for serving and eating.

column22:
Pre-metric units:
The unit "foot" is not usually understood outside of the English-speaking world.
One foot = 0.3048 metres.
For practical purposes, one foot can be taken to equal 30 centimeters and ten feet to equal three metres.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (pèra) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (pèrs) is used for a number that has been counted with precision.

Couple:
"In pèr" is Romansh is used like "a couple" in English to indicate "two or thereabouts".

People:
"Pievel" is used in the sense of a "population" or the "populace".
"Il pievel rumantsch" = "the Romansh people"
"Glieud" (which is grammatically singular and semantically plural) is used more in the sense of people in general.
"La glieud di che..." = "People say that..."

Popular initiative:
This is one of the ways of initiating legislation in Switzerland. Its instigators have to collect a certain number of valid signatures from registered voters within a limited period of time. If they succeed, the matter is voted on in a referendum usually held within 3-6 months. If the matter at stake is simple, a positive referendum vote can the force of law. More usually, a positive referendum vote is a binding instruction to government to produce draft legislation along particular lines. Popular initiatives are used at federal, cantonal and communal levels.

column22:
Trees and other plants:
Beware!
In Rumantsch Grischun and in the northern idioms, the word "planta" can mean either "plant" or "tree" (usually clear from context). The Engadin idioms have two separate words (like English).

Trees and other plants:
Beware!
In Rumantsch Grischun and in the northern idioms, the word "planta" can mean either "plant" or "tree" (usually clear from context). The Engadin idioms have two separate words (like English).

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (bos-cha) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (bös-chs/bos-schs) is used for a number counted with precision.
This particular instance concerns only the Engadin idioms, the other versions of Romansh have only the normal plural with an "s" (plantas).

As a very rough guide, the collective form (bos-cha) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (bös-chs) is used for a number that has been counted with precision.

column22:
Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "en il linguatg da la politica".

column23:
Num al singular + verb al plural:
I dat blers da tals cas en englais (almain en il linguatg pledà). I dependa da la perspectiva. Sch'ins considerescha che l'instituziun sa cumpona da plirs commembers singulars fan ins diever dal verb en il plural (il cas pli frequent). Sch'ins considerescha l'insitituziun sco in entitad unifurma fan ins adiever dal verb en il singular.

column22:
NEAT, Port'Alpina:
"NEAT" is the biggest and most expensive engineering project in Switzerland's history. New tunnels through the Alps are to enhance railway capacity enormously, cut journey times significantly and (hopeful) reduce the volume of road traffic.
The Gotthard Base Tunnel is to pass under Tujetsch (the highest part of Romansh-speaking Surselva) at a depth of 800 m below the village of Sedrun.
"Port'Alpina" is the name given to a proposal to build an underground station.

Animals and genders:
For many species Romansh has separate words for the male and the female, one of which is also used generally for the animal (for mixed genders or when gender is unknown or irrelevant).
Portg = pig
Ver = boar
Portga = sow
Latin: Sus domesticus
(animal species)

column22:
Swiss institutions:
The Swiss President is elected for a term of one calendar year from amongst the seven members of the Federal Council (in practice roughly in the order of their seniority). A long-standing Federal Councillor may well be elected Federal President more than once, but there must be a gap of at least one year (in practice several years) between each term. The President is elected jointly by the two houses of the Federal Parliament acting together as the "Federal Assembly".
The President's main function is to preside over the Federal Council.
It is not the Federal President alone who represents Switzerland abroad but the whole of the Federal Council.

The President is elected jointly by the two houses of the Federal Parliament acting together as the "Federal Assembly".
The President's main function is to preside over the Federal Council.
It is not the Federal President alone who represents Switzerland abroad but the whole of the Federal Council.

column22:
Swiss institutions:
In Graubünden, the function of "landamman" (particularly in southern parts of Graubünden) or "mistral" (particularly in northern parts of Graubünden) is a two-fold one: the political head of a "circul" (q.v.) and the head of the district court.
Generally, it is better to use the more modern term: "president(a) dal circul" (especially for a woman occupying the post).
In some of the other Swiss cantons, by the way, the "landamann" is the head of the cantonal government.

Problem:
Romansh (in common with many other European languages) has a word "problematica" in addition to "problem". Often it is simply a synonym; sometimes, it means the problem as a whole, the problem in context or even a set of problems.

Mintgatant èsi meglier d'agiuntar insatge, p.ex.: "the whole problem", "the real problem", "the problem area".
"Issue" sa esser ina schliaziun eleganta (p.ex. en in context politic).

column22:
Consultation:
The period of more of less formalised consultation between the government's announcement of its desire/intention to legislate and the actual parliamentary debate and vote on a specific proposal is an important element in the Swiss political system. All stakeholders have the opportunity of airing their view.

Procession:
"Cortegi" is the usual term in Romansh. It does not mean "funeral procession" like the English "cortege". "Til" is commonly used in some of the versions of Romansh. "Processiun" is available too.
column23:

Next (1):
in the sense of the next one to come. The adjective "proxim" is also used as a noun (= "next one").

Next (3):
In some idioms of Romansh, "auter" is used frequently for "next" in expressions of time:
"l'autra jamna" = "next week"
"l'auter onn" = "next year".
Otherwise use "proxim".

Next (2):
In some idioms of Romansh, "che vegn" is used frequently for "next" in expressions of time:
"l'emna che vegn" = "next week"
"l'onn che vegn" = "next year".
Cf. "the coming week" in English.
Otherwise use proxim.

Near East, Middle East:
What is now called the "Middle East" (from the American perspective) used to be called the "Near East" in British English. Most other European languages, including Romansh, have retained the concept of "Near East".
column23:

Assembly:
Romansh synonym: radunanza

Swiss institutions:
The "communal assembly" has had a strong position in Swiss history, which is now gradually disappearing. It is a gathering (organised at least once a year) open to all the electors of the commune and has legislative powers for that commune. In many places it is associated with considerable pageantry. The traditional practice of voting by show-of-hands is felt by many not to satisfy modern democratic criteria. All the large communes in Switzerland and many of the small ones have amended their constitutions to abolish the body and entrust local legislation to an elected council instead (whose decisions can often be challenged in a referendum). Some have kept the assembly but moved to ballot votes. Others have reduced the assembly to an advisory body only.

Graubünden geography:
The Rhine is fed by two tributaries which join up at Rheichenau (La Punt) in Graubünden. The northern one is known as the "Rain anteriur" ("Vorderrhein"), and the southern one as the "Rain posteriur" ("Hinterrhein").
Note that in Sutsilvan and Surmiran "ragn" is also used with a small "r" as a common noun for river or stream.

Internet / worldwide web:
That the two phenomena are not strictly the same worries very few speakers of any language. Romansh speakers tend to use "internet" for both. Sometimes they say "la Rait" for "the Web" .
The correct Romansh name for the letter W is "ve dubel". For "www", most Romansh people say "ve ve ve" (adopted from German).

column22:
Randulina:
Apart from being the bird (Latin: Hirundo rustica), "Randulin(a)" has a special meaning in Romansh (especially in the Engadin). It is applied to Romansh emigrants who go to live in other parts of the world who periodically return (like the swallow does every year).
This concept obviously meant more in times gone when travel was still very hazardous. Some of these "returnees" managed to make a fortune abroad and built themselves large mansions or summer residences back at home. One of the most widespread professions the "randulins" practiced abroad was cake-making, and Venice was one of the cities with the largest numbers of them.
(See also our note on "homesickness" or "encreschadetgna".)

Money:
The commonest term for "money" in (spoken) Romansh is "raps" which originally meant "centimes". "Daners" and "monaida" are also frequently used, the latter often meaning small change.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda realistica".

Advertising/advertisement(1):
In Romansh, different words may be used depending on the type of advertising/advertisement.
"Reclama" is the most widespread term.
column23:
Reclama:
En englais vegn il pled "advertisement" savens scursanì sin "ad", mintgatant sin "advert". La differenziaziun tranter reclama, inserat, euv. fan ins normalmain cun numnar il lieu: p.ex. in "inserat" fiss "an ad(vertisement) in a newspaper".
A nudar fiss er il suandant: "advertising" è la reclama en generala. "Advertisement" è ina suletta reclama.

column22:
Speech (4):
"Speech" in the sense of lecture.

Referendums:
Switzerland without referendums would be like Switzerland without mountains, cheese, chocolate, watches and Romansh. Unthinkable! Referendums are held at federal, cantonal and communal level.
There are different types:
(1) A parliamentary decision of constitutional significance MUST be confirmed by a referendum.
(2) Any ordinary law enacted by Parliament can be overturned in a referendum. The opponents must collect a certain number of valid signatures from registered voters within a set period of time and then win the referendum vote.
(3) A "popular initiative" with sufficient support can lead to a referendum vote to enact simple legislation directly or to instruct the government (Federal Council) to submit draft legislation to parliament with a defined purpose (which is the usual case today, since most issues tend to be rather complex).
Referendum votes are concentrated on four Sundays per year (usually in February, May, September and December) and are combined with any elections that are due. Taking all three levels, a Swiss voter will have around twenty referendum issues to decide on each year.
Turn-out varies greatly depending on the subjects concerned.
column23:
Plural englais:
Normalmain "referendums". Purist(a)s insisteschan sin il plural latin "referenda".

column22:
Churches:
The terms "refurmà", "protestant" and "evangelic" are basically synonymous in Romansh. Apart from the big centres, Switzerland does not have the same variety of denominations as is to be found in parts of the English-speaking word. Traditionally, each village decided on its (official) religion and had just one church. According to official statistics, there are roughly equal numbers of Catholics and Protestants in Graubünden, today.

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda regulara".

Remember, recall, remind, recollect:
In Romansh, "regurdar" is used for recalling something or reminding someone else of something and "sa regurdar" is used for remembering something oneself.
"Trair endament" / "far endament" is a more elegant expression for "remind" / "recall"
Note also the very common use in Romansh of "savair anc" for "remember" (literally "still know", i.e. not to have forgotten).
"Memorisar" is used for remembering in the sense of committing to memory.

column23:
Regurdar, sa regurdar, savair anc:
Ils different terms en englais chaschunan savens problems:
"Remember" è il pled normal per "sa regurdar".
"Recollect" è in term pli elegant per "sa regurdar".
"Remind" è il pled normal per "regurdar" (trair endament, far endament).
"Recall" po vegnir duvrà per "sa regurdar" e "regurdar".
Far attent al diever: "Let me remind you of what happened" u "Let me recall what happened for you."
En englais na datti nagin'expressiun che correspundess directamain a "savair anc".

Ina da las pli grondas difficultads per glieud ch'emprenda l'englais è da distinguer tranter "do" e "make", domadus signifitgeschan "far" en rumantsch. Il "tun" tudestg è normalmain "do". Il "machen" tudestg po esser "do" u "make".
Las differentas furmas da "do" vegnan normalmain cumbinadas cun il negativ "not": "don't", "doesn't", "didn't".

Renunziar, desister:
Star attent:

Exempel: la construcziun "nus renunziain ad in auto" vegn translatada cun "we do without a car" u simplamain "we haven't got a car".

Graubünden history:
Rhaetia was the historic name for a territory that overlapped with modern Graubünden. The adjective, Rhaetian, is still widely used in geographic designations and as a synonym for Graubünden (example: Rhaetian Railway).
The full scientific name for Romansh is Rhaeto-Romance.
Spelling: sometimes the "h" and occasionally the "a" may be left out.

column22:
Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda ritmica".

Romansh: rom (1):
"Rom" is used for the branch of a plant, river, etc.
"Branscha" is more usually used for sectors in industry and the like.
column23:

d'ina planta, euv.

column22:
Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (roma) is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (roms) is used for a number counted with precision.

Expressions with "avair":
Romansh has numerous expressions with "avair" ("have") plus a noun that correspond to expressions using "be" in English. In this instance: to "be thirsty" is "avair said" ("have thirst").

column22:
Hello, hi:
The greeting "bun di" is used on meeting people up until around midday/lunchtime. After that "buna saira" is used.
Learners often give themselves away with their first utterance in Romansh when they say "bun di" in the afternoon"!
In the Engadin "Allegra" is used at any time of the day.

Hello, hi:
The greeting "bun di" is used on meeting people up until around midday/lunchtime. After that "buna saira" is used.
Learners often give themselves away with their first utterance in Romansh when they say "bun di" in the afternoon"!
In the Engadin "Allegra" is used at any time of the day.

Evening:
"Sairada" is used for an evening spent doing something like being invited somewhere or attending some form of organised event.

Eventide:
There is no direct equivalent of "saira sontga" in modern English. It means the evening after work, a free evening, an evening of leisure. It corresponds approximately to the somewhat antiquated term "eventide".

Hedge:
The usual Romansh term for "hedge" is "saiv viva", literally: "living fence".

column22:
Sursilvan only:
Note that the plural of "schuldau" is "schuldaus" (not "schuldai", as might have been expected).

Collective feminine nouns in Romansh:
Romansh has numerous masculine nouns that not only have a normal plural in "-s" but a collective form too (a feminine singular noun formed by adding an "a" and possibly doubling the final consonant). No absolutely hard-and-fast rule can be given for the use of the two forms. As a very rough guide, the collective form (schuldada = "soldiery") is used for an indefinite number, and the plural in "s" (schuldads) is used for a number counted with precision.

column22:
Graubünden cuisine:
Barley soup is eaten throughout Graubünden. Traditionally, some bacon was added; today a vegetarian version is often available too.
Romansh synonyms: informaziun, scleriment

Graubünden institutions:
In Switzerland, primary education is a matter for the cantons, and in Graubünden the individual communes have retained considerable sovereignty in many primary-school matters, such as the language(s) of tuition.
In Graubünden, primary school lasts six years, nominally from age 6 to age 12.

Graubünden institutions:
The "scola secundara" in Graubünden caters for the age range of approximately 12-16.

Graubünden institutions:
This is the upper stage of the more academic stream of secondary education in Graubünden and the usual preparation for a university education to follow (approximate age range: 16-20).
It can be translated as "upper secondary school" (or "high school" in the American sense).

Graubünden institutions:
In Switzerland, secondary education is a matter for the cantons, which leads to massive differences.
In some cantons all (or nearly) all secondary schools have to be publicly owned and run.
In Graubünden, there are seven more academically demanding middle/upper-secondary schools, of which six are run by various private bodies (in Disentis/Mustér, Schiers, Davos, Samedan, Zuoz and Ftan). In Graubünden there is only one "cantonal school". It provides education at this level in Chur.

Teach (1):
"Dar scola" is the commonest Romansh term for to teach, to be a teacher.

Graubünden institutions:
Many Graubünden communes have a considerable area of forest on their territories. It plays a considerable role in tourism and the environment, it may be commercially exploited, and, not least, it often provides protection against avalanches and landslides. In such communes the forestry officer's job is an important one.

In such communes the forestry officer's job is an important one.

Term, semester:
Whereas the academic year is traditionally divided up into three terms in many English-speaking countries, much of continental Europe, including Switzerland, divides it up into two semesters

column22:
Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "en ina furma separada".

column22:
Swiss geography - towns and cities
Authentic local names:
The tradition of using French names (such as St. Gall) in English for non-French-speaking places in Switzerland and elsewhere is to be considered increasingly obsolete. Modern practice is to use authentic local names (in this case: St. Gallen).
See "Graubünden" for a detailed explanation.

Swiss cantons (16):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons.
Canton St. Gallen joined in 1803 (replacing seven former smaller terriotiries).
The name "St. Gall" is also sometimes used in English (but increasingly rarely).
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: SG
Capital: St. Gallen
Official language: German
Population (approx.): 460 000
Surface area: 2026 square kilometres
Many place names in the south of the canton end in "s" (or "z") - a characteristic of the Mediaeval Romansh that used to be spoken there many centuries ago.

Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates them to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.

Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates the points of the compass to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.

AIDS:
In the spoken language, the English word "aids" is generally used. In written texts, especially official ones, "sida" is frequently encountered. SIDA stands for "sindrom d'immunitad defizienta acquistada". Both terms are masculine.

Mister (Mr.):
When "signur" (or "sar") is used as a title (= "Mr.") it is generally written with a small "s" unlike English. "Sar" in the Engadin is often used in combination with a man's first name, a practice unknown in the rest of Graubünden.

Mister (Mr.):
When "signur" (or "sar") is used as a title (= "Mr.") it is generally written with a small "s" unlike English. "Sar" in the Engadin is often used in combination with a man's first name, a practice unknown in the rest of Graubünden.

Graubünden geography:
A region of Graubünden. The Rhine valley between the river Landquart and the cantonal boundary with St. Gallen. Famous, inter alia, for its wines and the Heidi story. It is predominantly German-speaking, hence its German name is the one usually used in English. Often shortened to just "Herrschaft".

Romansh has many precise expressions of absolute and relative position that it is difficult to render accurately in other languages. These are the outcome of the traditional valley-dweller using the valley's topography as a reference system.

Las differentas furmas da "do" vegnan normalmain cumbinadas cun il negativ "not": "don't", "doesn't", "didn't".

Ice saints / "Three Saints:

Priest, etc. (03)

Priest, etc. (04)
Romansh has a multiplicity of terms (some of them overlapping) depending which religion in involved.

Priest, etc. (05)
Romansh has a multiplicity of terms (some of them overlapping) depending which religion in involved.
"Ravarenda" and, more recently, "ravarendessa" are commonly used terms in Protestant churches in the Engadin.
// Note that "minister" is only used in the political sense in Romansh, not in any religious sense.

Priest, etc. (06)
Romansh has a multiplicity of terms (some of them overlapping) depending which religion in involved.
"Plevon" and "preditgant(a)" are mainly used in Protestant churches.
Note that "plevonessa" traditional means "minister's wife" and not "female minister".
Note too that "minister" is only used in the political sense in Romansh, not in any religious sense.

column22:
Graubünden and its people:
The traditional form of livestock farming in the Alps is known technically as "transhumance". The animals (and their herdsmen) spend the warmer part of the year at higher altitudes. They are brought back down to the valley during the colder months (which they usually spend indoors). "Ir ad alp" (or "chargiada") is the process of going up to the higher pastures in the spring. In some villages, it is still associated with a traditional ceremony. A much more widespread and a colourful spectacle is the descent back down from the alps in the autumn - the "stgargiada".

column22:
Esteemed:
"Stimà... / Stimada" is a common way of starting a letter to someone with whom you are not on familiar terms.
It is also used when making speeches:
"Stimadas (dunnas), stimads (signurs)" = "Ladies and gentlemen".
"Stimada raspada" = "Esteemed gathering"

Writing letters(1):
Beginnings:
In English nearly all correspondence can begin with "Dear". In Romansh, "char(a)" is only used with relatives and close friends. "Stimà"/"stimada" (= "esteemed") is a more formal opening. "Prezià"/"preziada" is somewhere between the two.
column23:
Scriver brevs e postels:
L'entschatta:
Bunamain tut las brevs en englais (cun l'excepziun da las pli formalas u las pli intimas) entschaivan cun "Dear..." (adina cun in grond D).
Ma Adatg! Quest "dear" na vegn strusch duvrà en il linguatg pledà e tuna plitost affectà en englais! Expressiuns sco "dear guests", "dear visitors" e.u.v. èn in mintga cas dad evitar en il linguatg pledà.

Idiomatic usage:
A very common expression in Romansh is "chattar la storta" (to manage to negotiate a bend - as in a car). It is also used figuratively, especially in the negative (betg chattar la storta = "to miss a bend", to come unstuck", "to fail", etc.)

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "ord motivs strategics".

Stuair:
"Must" è in verb incumplet en englais:
Per quellas parts da "must" che n'existan betg, dovr'ins per exempel la furma correspundenta da have to.
La muntadas da las furmas negativas fissan da nudar: (1): I must not play football in the street. = Jau na sto betg dar ballape sin via.
(2) I don't have to play foot ball in the street. = Jau na vegn betg sfurzà a dar ballape sin via.

column22:
Romansh synonyms:
"Stuf" and "unfis" are more or less synonyms.

Romansh: Pulit:
"Pulit" is a much-used adjective in Romansh. Like the English, "nice", "fine" (or even "OK" or "cool"), it is used in many circumstances.
"Pulit" and "flot" are often interchangeable.
A frequent reply to "Cu vai?" ("how are you?") is "i va pulit" ("I'm fine).

Romansh: flot
"Flot" (which has been assimilated into Romansh from German) corresponds roughly to English expressions such as "nice and elegant", "nice and fast", etc. It is more or less synonymous with the present-day use of "cool" in English, which has also been imported into Romansh!
"Flot" and "pulit" are often interchangeable"

Cool:
The English "cool", in its slang sense, has been assimilated into Romansh and is possible used even more by young Romansh speakers than be their English-speaking counterparts!

column22:
Apple juice, cider:
"Most" is the commonest word in Switzerland for apple juice, whether fermented or not. You may well be served with cider, unless you stress "most dultsch". Similarly, in parts of Graubünden, a "cider dultsch" is not sweet cider but straightforward, unfermented apple juice.

Expressions with "avair":
Romansh has numerous expressions with "avair" (have) plus a noun that correspond to English expressions with "be" plus an adjective. In this instance: to have success rather than to be successful.
"Reussir" is an alternative to "avair success".

column22:
Graubünden geography:
Surmeir written "Surmir" in most versions of Romansh) is a region in central Graubünden where the Surmiran idiom of Romansh is spoken. Surses is one of the larger valleys within that region. Both translate into German as "Oberhalbstein", which can be the cause of confusion.

One of the five traditional written idioms of Romansh, used in parts of Central Graubünden, especially Surmeir. Note that languages are usually written with a small letter in Romansh.

column22:
Graubünden geography:
Surselva ("Bündner Oberland" in German) is the most north-westerly large valley in Canton Graubünden (the valley of the "Vorderrhein", one of the tributaries of the river Rhine). It is the home of Sursilvan, the idiom of Romansh with the largest number of speakers today.

Graubünden geography:
Surselva is the home of Sursilvan, the idiom of Romansh with the largest number of speakers today.
Its German name is "Bündner Oberland".
"Surselva" in combination with an adjective is also used for other mountainous regions, notably "Sursevla bernaisa" (= Bernese Oberland).

Graubünden geography:
Surmeir (written "Surmir" in most versions of Romansh) is a region in central Graubünden where the Surmiran idiom of Romansh is spoken. Surses is one of the larger valleys within that region. Both translate into German as "Oberhalbstein", which can be the cause of confusion.

Sursilvan (1):
One of the five traditional written idioms of Romansh, used in Surselva. Note that languages are usually written with a small letter in Romansh.

column22:
Swiss cantons (14):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons, of which six are half-cantons, created by the division of former larger cantons. Nidwalden is one of there half-cantons (a status it achieved legally in 1803). As part of the former Canton Unterwalden, it had been one of the founding members of the Swiss Confederation in 1291.
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: NW
Capital: Stans
Official language: German
Population (approx.): 40 000
Surface area: 276 square kilometres
column23:

column22:
Sovereign:
In Switzerland, it is the people as a whole who are the sovereign. You will often encounter expressions such as "il suveran ha decidì" (= "the sovereign (people) has decided", i.e. in a referendum).
Switzerland also has a collegiate head of state, namely the seven-member Federal Council (q.v.).

column22:
Half-Fare Card:
Very popular in Switzerland. Holders of such cards can travel on most public-transport routes throughout Switzerland at a discount of up to 50%. The annual price of the basic entitlement card is very modest, and it is only necessary to travel a few hundred kilometres to achieve a breakeven compared with full fares.

Tea:
In Switzerland (as in much of continental Europe), many different plants are used for teas/infusions. If you want something approximating to the traditional British "cuppa", order a "té nair" (= black tea) and say that you want milk (= latg) with it, not lemon.

Time:
The general-purpose word for "time" in Romansh is "temp".
"Ura" (which also means "hour") is used for the time on the clock.
"Peda" is used for having time available to do something.
To have time for something is "avair temp" or "avair peda". But there is a big difference! "Avair temp" simply means having a spare slot in one's diary. "Avair peda" means finding time or making time available for a commitment. (Sometimes the two words are combined: "Avais temp e peda?" (Do you have time for...")
Note the saying: "I dat bain umans che han ina massa temp, mo nagina peda." ("There are people with plenty of time to spare, but never any time to really do anything.")
column23:
Temp, peda:
En englais na datti nagina differenza natirala tranter "temp" e "peda".

Avoidance of long adverbs in Romansh:
Many Romansh adjectives can be turned into adverbs by adding the ending "-(a)main" (or the regional equivalent). This is like adding "-ly" to an English adjective. These long adverbs are, however, often awkward to pronounce, so it is common practice (especially in the spoken language) is to replace them with an expression like "d'ina moda terribla".

"Timun", which originally means rudder, and "timunar", which originally means to steer a ship with its rudder, have become common expressions for "power", "control" or even the person in control in modern Romansh.

Venir al timun = come to power

column22:
Marksman:
The marksman is an important figure in Swiss history. The tradition is kept alive through numerous associations called "uniuns da tir" who organise regular competitions or festivals to find the best marksman. These festival are known as "festas da tir". Traditionally, these were often part of fairs.
This practice is also closely linked to Switzerland's militia army. All solders keep their weapons at home and are called up at least one a year to show that they can still use them effectively (this is known in Romansh as the "tir obligatori".)

column22:
Bay window:
This is the usual translation of "balcun tort", although it gives only an approximate idea of this famous architectural feature found especially in older houses in the Engadin. Most traditional house windows were recessed, thus offering only a limited view of what was happening on the street in front of the building. The protruding V-shaped "balcun tort" (about big enough for one person) was an excellent vantage point for seeing happenings up and down the street and represented an important form of "social control".

The usual Romansh word for "negotiate" is "tractar"/"contractar". "Negoziar" is used primarily in the political sense.

Negotiation(s) (1):
The usual Romansh word for "negotiations" is "tractativas" (generally used in the plural as in English - in some idioms only in the plural). "Negoziaziun" is used primarily in the political sense.

Negotiation(s) (2):

column22:
Remember, recall, remind, recollect:
In Romansh, "regurdar" is used for recalling something or reminding someone else of something and "sa regurdar" is used for remembering something oneself.
"Trair endament" / "far endament" is a more elegant expression for "remind" / "recall"
Note also the very common use in Romansh of "savair anc" for "remember" (literally "still know", i.e. not to have forgotten).
"Memorisar" is used for remembering in the sense of committing to memory.
column23:
Regurdar, sa regurdar, savair anc:
Ils different terms en englais chaschunan savens problems:
"Remember" è il pled normal per "sa regurdar".
"Recollect" è in term pli elegant per "sa regurdar".
"Remind" è il pled normal per "regurdar" (trair endament, far endament).
"Recall" po vegnir duvrà per "sa regurdar" e "regurdar".
Far attent al diever: "Let me remind you of what happened" u "Let me recall what happened for you."
En englais na datti nagin'expressiun che correspundess directamain a "savair anc".

column22:
Favugn, föhn:
The "föhn" or "favugn" is a hot downwind. This weather phenomenon is caused when a wet wind cools slowly as it ascends the Alps, loosing its precipitation, and then warms up again much faster as it descends in a drier state. It is blamed for all sorts of disorders affecting people and animals.
The usual Romansh expression is "i trai favugn" (= "there's a föhn blowing").
Complication:
The word "fö(h)n/favugn" is sometimes also used in Romansh and German to mean "hair dryer"!

Graubünden customs:
This was once a widespread custom in Switzerland. It is believed that it was originally a courtship/fertility rite. A few villages still practise it today, including Dardin, Danis and Tavanasa in Surselva.
After nightfall on the Saturday following Ash Wednesday, the young men gather above the village and light a big bonfire. They heat up discs of elm wood ("schibettas"), which somewhat resemble modern frisbees with a small hole in the middle. When these are red hot, they are taken out of the fire on thin sticks and hurled though the air down the valley, flying considerable distances. As it is thrown, each schibetta is dedicated to one of the young women of the village. The thrower shouts out her name. Whilst this is going on, the young women of the village make special large biscuits ("patlaunas"), which they share with the young men when they return from their exertions.

"Carnival" is the period from 11 November up until the start of Lent. It remains a popular tradition in many parts of Graubünden, especially in Catholic communities.

Mist, fog:
Modern city dwellers are used to making a distinction between "fog" (which is bad) and "mist" (which is associated more with the countryside and may thus even be considered pleasant). Romansh does not make such a clear distinction. "Tschajera" comes nearest to "fog". "Brentina" is often a rising morning mist, which at some seasons of the year can be quite stunning!

Adjectives used as nouns.
Many Romansh adjectives are used as nouns. Just put an article in front of them. There is no need for a word corresponding to the English "one".
Example:
Il tschorv, la tschorva = the blind man, the blind woman.

Adjectives used as nouns.

Graubünden geography:
The Domleschg (in German) or Tumleastga (in Romansh) is a broad valley in central northern Graubünden crossed by the Hinterrhein tributary of the Rhine and famous for its castles (most of them now ruins).
Only a small percentage of the population still speaks the traditional language, Romansh (Sutsilvan). German now very much dominates.

column22:
Humans, Christians:
Traditionally, some versions of Romansh made no distinction between the word for "human being" and "Christian" and other terms derived from them.
The modern trend (especially in the standardised Rumantsch Grischun) is to use the unambiguous terms "uman(a)" and "crisitian(a)", although "carstgaun(a)" is still the usual term for "human being" in some of the Romansh idioms today.
Note also the use of the small "c" in Romansh: cristian(a).

column22:
Marksman:
The marksman is an important figure in Swiss history. The tradition is kept alive through numerous associations called "uniuns da tir" who organise regular competitions or festivals to find the best marksman. These are known as "festas da tir". Traditionally, these festivals were often part of fairs.
This practice is also closely linked to Switzerland's militia army. All solders keep their weapons at home and are called up at least one a year to show that they can still use them effectively (this is known in Romansh as the "tir obligatori".)

Swiss cantons - adjectives:
For most Swiss cantons, there is a separate adjective in Romansh, which is the same as the name for that canton's citizens, but normally written with a small letter. For certain expressions, the use of "da" (of) is preferred. In English, we either use the noun in an adjectival position or an expression with "of".

Traditionally, votes/ballot papers were collect in an urn. In numerous Romansh expressions, "urna" is used as a symbol for voting and elections.

Animals and genders:
For many species Romansh has separate words for the male and the female, one of which is also used generally for the animal (for mixed genders or when gender is unknown or irrelevant).
Urs = bear
Urs = he-bear
Ursa = she-bear
Latin: Ursus arctos
Urs is also a popular first name in Switzerland.

column22:
Swiss cantons (23):
The Swiss Confederation is comprised of 26 cantons.
Canton Vaud joined in 1803.
Here are a few facts and figures:
Official abbreviation: VD
Capital: Lausanne
Official language: French
Population (approx.): 650 000
Surface area: 3212 square kilometres.
column23:
Chantuns svizzers - lur nums en englais:

column22:
Swiss cantons - adjectives:
For most Swiss cantons, there is a separate adjective in Romansh, which is the same as the name for that canton's citizens, but normally written with a small letter. For certain expressions, the use of "da" (of) is preferred. In English, we either use the noun in an adjectival position or an expression with "of".
column23:
Chantuns svizzers - adjectivs:
En bunamain tut ils cas na datti nagin adjectiv englais per ils chantuns svizzers. Tenor il cas, fan ins adiever dal num sco adjectiv u d'in'expressiun cun "of".
Sc'alternativa san ins er far adiever da l'adjectiv franzos "Vaudois" (ma adina scrit cun in grond bustab).

column22:
Old:
The usual word for old is "vegl". "Veder" is used when there is something special about the oldness or antiqueness, such as "mature" foods like cheese or the "Old Testament" ("Veder Testament"). Sometimes "veder" is simply "very old".
column23:
Veder:
L'englais n'ha betg in term singul che correspundess al pled rumantsch "veder". Tut tenor fan ins adiever da "old" u sulet u (en cumbinaziun cun in auter pled) u d'in auter term.

column22:
Cardinal compass points:
(north, south, east, west)
Romansh has two words for each of these. One set resembles the English terms. The other set equates the points of the compass to the time of day (east = morning, south = midday, west = evening, north = midnight). The two sets of terms are used roughly equally.
column24:
Els stattan al vest da l'Engalterra. =

Viafier:
Il term "railway" è plitost britannic ed il term "railroad" è plitost american, ma ins chatta domadus terms da domaduas varts da l'Atlanic.

column22:
The Rhaetian Railway's splendid metre-gauge network serves all the major valleys of Canton Graubünden and connects with bus services to nearly all the Canton's villages. The railway includes many marvellous works of engineering and offers numerous spectacular views. A must for any visitor to Graubünden!
Most visitors arrive from the north using the standard-gauge federal railway and need to change in Landquart or Chur.

column11: Swiss Federal Railways, SBB, CFF, FRS, VFF
column22:
Swiss Federal Railways:
This organisation has four names in each of the Swiss national languages - and four abbreviations to go with them:
Romansh: Viafiers federalas svizras (VFF)
German: Schweizerische Bundesbahnen (SBB)
French: Chemins de fer fédéraux (CFF)
Italian: Ferrovie federali svizzere (FFS)
Very regrettably, the company does not consider it necessary to make regular use of the Romansh version alongside the others.
Romansh speakers often use the German abbreviation, SBB or talk about "la Federala".

column23:

column22:
Swiss institutions:
Traditionally, the "mischance bernaisa" (roughly: "organised community of citizens") has existed alongside the political commune in Switzerland. Its role is to look after "non-political matters", especially welfare, but also culture. There is an accelerating trend for these separate civil communities to disband and/or to be assimilated within the political communes. Each one has full sovereignty to decide on its own fate.

column22:
Cheers:
"Viva!" is used for "cheers" when drinking to someone's health and also for "bless you!" when someone sneezes.
The term is invariable expect for Sutsilvan, where a distinction is made between saying "cheers" to one person or to several people.
column23:
Viva:
Il term usità per "viva!" en englais è "cheers". "Cheerio" din ins er, ma quest term po er signifitgar "a revair!". "(Here's to) your (very) good health" è in'expressiun bler pli formala.
Sco reacziun sin ina starnidada din ins "bless you!".

column22:
Graubünden geography and history:
The Valtellina is a valley immediately to the south of Graubünden, which today belongs to Italy. It used to be part of Graubünden (the State of the Three Leagues) until 1797. Its (red) wine has remained popular in Graubünden (which is not self-sufficient in the beverage).

Note that the first syllable "vu..." is frequently dropped especially in the first person singular in the spoken language: "Jau less" (vuless) = "I would like".

column22:
Graubünden geography:
A Romansh-speaking village in Surselva, the only village in the whole region to turn to protestantism at the time of the Reformation and to have maintained that difference for many centuries. It has one of the region's most famous ruined medieval castles (Munt Sogn Gieri/Jörgenburg) as well as one of Switzerland's oldest and most successful ecological hotels, the "Ucliva".

column22:
Pre-metric units:
Temperatures:
Outside of the English-speaking world, virtually no-one understands degrees Fahrenheit, so it's better to use degrees Celsius.
To convert, take the value in Fahrenheit, subtract 32, divide by 9 and multiply 5.
column23:
Unitads na-metricas:
L'unitad "Fahrenheit" na vegn oz strusch pli duvrada en contexts scientifics. Ella resta dentant fitg populara tar la glieud en general, surtut tar la glieud pli veglia.
0°C = 32° F
100°C = 212°F
La scala Fahrenheit sa basava oriundamain sin la temperatura supponida normala dal corp uman (= 100°F). Questa valur è atgnamain in zic memia auta.
Per convertir ina valur da Fahrenheit en Celsius, ston ins l'emprim deducir 32 e suenter multiplitgar cun 5/9.
La temperatura exprimida sco grads Celsius e sco grads Fahrenheit è la medema a -40°.

column22:

column22:
Bell (1):
Romansh has many terms for "bell" (especially as worn by animals) depending on size, shape and material.
"Scalin" is used for a bike bell, a front-door bell or a cast-metal bell as typically worn by goats.

Bell (2):
Romansh has many terms for "bell" (especially as worn by animals) depending on size, shape and material.
"Stgella" is the best general-purpose term for a smallish bell worn by an animal.

Bell (3):
Romansh has many terms for "bell" (especially as worn by animals) depending on size, shape and material.
"Brunsina" is "bell-shaped bell" as worn by animals. It is also used for bell-shaped flowers.

Bell (4):
Romansh has many terms for "bell" (especially as worn by animals) depending on size, shape and material.
"Plumpa" is a particularly large oval-shaped bell worn by adult cattle.

Bell (5):
Romansh has many terms for "bell" (especially as worn by animals) depending on size, shape and material.
"Zain" is a church bell or the like.

column22:
Romansh verbs (9):
Verbs with the "-el" ending in their first person singular:
 "Zambregiar" is one of these. To view its full conjugation, click "Details". 
In Rumantsch Grischun, the first-person singular normally has no ending. Whenever the verb stem ends in a palatalised consonant, a consonant cluster or an "i", "...el" is added.
In Sursilvan, most verbs have this ending.
column23:
Verbs irregulars englais:
(1)
Infinitiv: do
Preschent: I/we/you/they do, he/she/it/one does
Passà simpel: did
Particip: done
(2)
Infinitiv/preschent: make
Passà simpel: made
Particip: made
Ina da las pli grondas difficultads per glieud ch'emprenda englais è da distinguer tranter "do" e "make", domadus signifitgeschan "far" en rumantsch. Il "tun" tudestg è normalmain "do". Il "machen" tudestg po esser "do" u "make".
Las differentas furmas da "do" vegnan normalmain cumbinadas cun il negativ "not": "don't", "doesn't", "didn't".
I na dat betg in pled en englais per "zambregiar". La meglra expressiun dependa dal context. Per exempel: per "jau zambregel gugent" pudess ins dir "I like making things".

Low-calorie food and drink:
Whereas the usual English expression is "Diet ", Romansh (along with other languages) has adopted the English word "light", which is placed after the object.
Example:
Diet Coke, Diet Pepsi, etc. = cola light.

Englais: "penny":
In penny è in tschientavel dad ina glivra (munaida britannica). Avant la refurma da la munaida (l'uschenumnada "decimalisation") en 1971 faschevan 12 vegls pennies in shilling e 20 shillings ina glivra. Il linguatg englais cuntegna bleras expressiuns cun il pled "penny". Penny è er in num popular da dunnas.
Il plural da "penny" è "pence" per inditgar in pretsch e "pennies" per inditgar il dumber da munaidas.

Per latg din ins "pinta" (scursanì da "pint of milk").
column24: He likes his pint. = El baiva gugent birra.

Englais "farthing":
Ina veglia munaida britannica cun in'istorgia da bunamain milli onns fin 1960. Sia valur actuala fiss ca. CHF 0.002. Il pled è restà en pliras expressiuns en englais britannic.

Graubünden history:
Rhaetia was the historic name for a territory that overlapped with modern Graubünden. The adjective, Rhaetian, is still widely used in geographic designations and as a synonym for Graubünden (example: Rhaetian Railway).
The full scientific name for Romansh is Rhaeto-Romance.
Spelling: sometimes the "h" and occasionally the "a" may be left out.
column23:
Rezia, retic:
Glieud dal mund anglofon (cun l'excepziun da spezialist(a)s) na chapeschen betg automaticamain quests terms, cura ils vegnan duvrads bunamain sco sinonims per Grischun.

Thou, thee, thy, thine:
This singular form has died out in modern English, and we call everybody "you". Not so in many European languages, including Romansh! There are different ways of saying you, depending on how well you know people and whether you're talking to one person or several.
Click "details" for a full explanation.
column25:
You/your: 

Saying "you" is much more complicated in Romansh than English.

In standardised Rumantsch Grischun the following distinction is made:
(1) "Ti" is used for talking to ONE relative, close friend, child, animal, etc. 
The normal accusative/dative of "ti" is "ta" and it comes BEFORE the verb.
The emphatic accusative/dative of "ti" is "(a) tai" and it comes AFTER the verb.
The corresponding form of "your" is "tes", "tia" or "tias" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
The corresponding form of "yours" or "your one" is " il tieu", "ils tieus" "la tia" or "las tias" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
(2) "Vus" is always used for the plural and is also when talking to one adult who is not a relative, close friend, etc.
The normal accusative/dative of "vus" is "as" and it comes BEFORE the verb.
The emphatic accusative/dative of "vus" is "(a) vus" and it comes AFTER the verb.
The corresponding form of "your" is "voss", "vossa" or "vossas" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).
The corresponding form of "yours" or "your one" is " il voss", "ils voss" "la vossa" or "las vossas" (depending on the gender and number of the noun referred to).

Surmiran follows more or less the same practice as Rumantsch Grischun.

Sursilvan has only the form that comes after the verb, whether emphatic or not.

Sutsilvan mainly uses the form after the verb, whether emphatic or not; the form before the verb still theoretically exists but is little used in the modern language.

Puter and Vallader have an added complication: 
(1) "Tü" is used in the same way as the other versions of Rumantsch.
(2) "Vus" is used as the plural of "tü", i.e. for talking to more than one child, close friend, etc.
(3) The polite way to address one person is to use the third person ("he/him", "she/her"), and the polite way to address several people is to use "they/them". In the written language capital letters are used to distinguish between this "polite you" and the "genuine" third person.

In all versions of Romansh, it is usual to use a capital letter for you/your/yours in letters and e-mails.

column23:
Englais "o'clock":
... inditgescha uras cumplainas dad 1 a 12.
Exempel: "igl è las trais" = "It's three o'clock."
En englais dovr'ins savens "a.m" per inditgar l'avantmezdi (fin 11:59) e "p.m." per inditgar il suentermezdi (davent da 12:00). En in tal cas lasch'ins davent il "o'clock".
Exempel: "igl è las trais (las quindesch)" = u "it's three p.m" u "it's three o'clock in the afternoon".
Adatg: "12 a.m." = mesanotg e "12 p.m." = mezdi!
"O'clock" na vegn mai duvrà en cumbinaziun cun las cifras 13-24. L'expressiun la pli correcta per "15:00" è "fifteen hundred hours".

column22:
Coals to Newcastle:
There are several equivalent expressions in Romansh. This is one of the two commonest.
The Valtellina is a valley immediately to the south of Graubünden, which today belongs to Italy. It used to be part of Graubünden (the State of the Three Leagues) until 1797. Its (red) wine has remained popular in Graubünden (which is not self-sufficient in the beverage).
column23:
Purtar aua en il Rain, euv.:
Pli baud era il port da Newcastle (nordost da l'Engalterra) in dals centers ils pli impurtants per l'export da charvun. I fiss vairamain stà davanz da purtar anc dapli charvun a Newcastle!
